{"doc_id": "list1635.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list1636.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 13, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. {"doc_id": "list1640.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list1642.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list1644.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list1670.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 24, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list1671.txt", "event" : "College of LAS: For Faculty & Staff: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list1733.txt", "event" : "The College of Veterinary Medicine at Illinois: Illini Summer Academy", "date" : " Jun 22, 2015 - Jun 24, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "University of Illinois", "bio" : "Are you interested in animals, medicine, and science? Do you like helping people? Do you like unraveling mysteries? Do you like real challenges? If you answered yes to these questions, then the wide world of veterinary medicine just may be for you. Veterinarians have a strong interest and ability in science. They enjoy working with people as well as with animals. Take a step into the world of veterinary medicine and see what veterinary school is like, learn about the different aspects of veterinary medicine, and more. You will learn about the science of veterinary medicine, anatomy, immunology, bacteriology, parasitology, wildlife medicine, large and small animal medicine, and more. You will participate in clinical equine rounds, streak and read bacteriology slides, learn about veterinary specialty fields such as dentistry, ophthalmology, and forensic pathology, and so much more."}

{"doc_id": "list1956.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list1957.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list1993.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2012.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Krannert Center Tour", "date" : " May 2, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Lobby", "bio" : "Meet in the Lobby in front of the Ticket Office to take a peek inside our nooks and crannies and learn more about Krannert Center. Each tour is given by a member of the Krannert Center Student Association, one of our Krannert Center Community Volunteers, or a staff member who will tell you about construction of the building, lead you onto stages, and take you into our production areas."}

{"doc_id": "list2013.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2014.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 3, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2016.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list2033.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2042.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2051.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2052.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Machine Translation Conference", "date" : " May 10, 2015 - May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Lincoln Room, I-Hotel and Conference Center, 1900 S. First Street, Champaign.", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2053.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 12, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2054.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 12, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2066.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2089.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2090.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: KAM Exhibition | With the Grain: Japanese Woodblock Prints from the Postwar Years", "date" : " May 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Krannert Art Museum Asian Gallery", "bio" : "Printmaking flourished in Japan during"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2091.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 21, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2092.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2093.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 22, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list2117.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list2128.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 31, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2133.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: “Art and Architecture of a Forgotten Kingdom”", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight  Auditorium, Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory St., Urbana", "bio" : "The Hellenistic kingdom of Syracuse in eastern Sicily fell to Rome at the end of the Second Punic War. As a result of this violent conquest many of the achievements of the preceding half-century of peace came to be obscured and even forgotten under Roman domination, and to some extent they have remained so to the present day. The death in the siege of Syracuse of the great scientist and mathematician Archimedes can symbolize the enormous cultural losses of this moment of violent change. The lecture casts light on the innovative and progressive character of earlier Syracusan Hellenistic art through works of sculpture, mosaic, terracotta, and silver, as well as the ambitious architectural programs of the metropolis of Syracuse and other cities within the kingdom, including Akrai and Morgantina."}

{"doc_id": "list2146.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: Bandung Resurrected: Third World Solidarity, Asian Regionalism, and South Korean Literature", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. Mathews Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "At the historic Bandung Conference in 1955, there was a seat at the table reserved for Japan but none for Japan’s two earliest colonies--Taiwan and Korea. Led by Nehru and profoundly shaped by the history of European colonialisms, the Bandung Conference found no place within its framework for a former colony of an Asian imperial power, now consumed by US-Soviet rivalry. Dead on arrival in the postwar 1950s, the Bandung spirit of anti-colonialism and non-alignment would nevertheless find itself reborn in Korea two decades later as the discourse of Third World Literature. This talk examines the unavowed legacy of the Bandung Conference in guiding South Korean literature’s turn toward political engagement and addresses how the dilemma of Bandung for Japan’s former colony informed the reanimation of Asian regionalism in South Korea at the end of the twentieth century. This reanimation took place in creative tension with the concept of world literature on the one hand and the historical specter of the Greater East Asian Co-prosperity Sphere on the other. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2168.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AND CULTURES - Chinese Table", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "2050 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Chinese Table is open to students who are learning Chinese at all levels as well as Chinese native speakers who are interested in participating in the conversation. {"doc_id": "list2169.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Manuscripts surviving from the eastern Silk Road site of Dunhuang make possible, among many studies, close explorations of the ways Chinese Buddhists of the ninth and tenth centuries constructed ritual programs. In this talk I will examine three features of those constructions: the natures of the frames by which Buddhist cultic texts--narrative scriptures and incantations--were made the focuses of recitation rites, the borrowings and adaptations of existing materials of which those frames were made, and the understandings of the nature of scriptural language implicit in these practices. I will also consider what these sources can tell us about the history of Buddhism in premodern China more broadly."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2201.txt", "event" : "Cultural & International Calendar | ILLINOIS: UK and Ireland Scholarships Informational Session and Application Workshop", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB 514)", "bio" : "Join us to learn about a group of nationally competitive scholarships that fully fund graduate study in the United Kingdom and Ireland! This informational session and application workshop is targeted to juniors, seniors, and graduate or professional students, and will provide an overview of the Gates Cambridge, Marshall, Mitchell, and Rhodes scholarships.  We will discuss basic eligibility requirements, selection criteria, and the application processes for these awards.  The latter portion of the event is designed to introduce some of the common application components for the scholarships and help participants start to develop content for them.  This is a great opportunity to strategize and get feedback on your ideas for your personal statement and other written portions of the applications.  The priority deadline for the Marshall and Gates Cambridge scholarships is June 1, 2015, and the required campus deadline for many of the UK/Ireland scholarships is August 25, 2015, so now is the time to learn about the programs and get answers to your questions!"}

{"doc_id": "list2526.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

Wright, Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "NOW's purpose is to take action to bring women into full participation in the mainstream of American society now, exercising all privileges and responsibilities thereof in truly equal partnership with men. This purpose includes, but is not limited to, equal rights and responsibilities in all aspects of citizenship, public service, employment, education, and family life, and it includes freedom from discrimination because of race, ethnic origin, age, marital status, sexual preference/orientation, or parenthood."}

{"doc_id": "list2541.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: Yoga for Healing I Women on the Move", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 5:30 pm - 6:30 pm  ", "location" : "Second Floor, Women’s Resources Center, 703 S. Wright, Champaign", "bio" : "If you’ve been curious about yoga but hesitant to join an ongoing class, the WRC welcomes you to a yoga for healing class. We will begin with a background of yoga including philosophy, fundamental components of a yoga class, and styles of yoga. We will explore yoga breathing practices and learn some basic yoga poses, with an emphasis on safe movement and effective alignment. Our practice will conclude with a final relaxation period. Yoga for Healing is a safe space, survivor-centered and designed for bodies of all shapes, sizes, and abilities. Dress in clothes that are easy to move around in!"}

{"doc_id": "list2542.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: Take Back the Night", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 6:30 pm  ", "location" : "Lincoln Square, 300 S. Broadway, Urbana", "bio" : "Take Back the Night is a march and rally to end sexual violence. This is event is open to everyone. Participants will gather at 6:30p.m. at Lincoln Square Mall and will march West towards campus starting at 7p.m. A speak-out will be held on the Engineering Quad after the march (around 8p.m.) where survivors and supporters will be encouraged to share their experiences with the group. Weather information: We will march in any weather conditions as long as it isn't a safety risk to the group (i.e. severe lightening, tornado, etc.)."}

{"doc_id": "list2554.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: ManTalks", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 7:00 pm  ", "location" : "Second Floor, Women’s Resources Center, 703 S. Wright, Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "What makes a man? This question is rarely asked and even more rarely discussed - especially by men. ManTalks is an opportunity to discuss men's issues in today's society. Each talk will be open conversation about a different topic concerning the development of men and the role that society plays in manhood. From how work defines us to sharing our emotions, ManTalks looks to examine how men are able to be who they want to be. Come join the conversation about men, with men, in an environment that hopes to challenge the status quo and push the boundaries of what a man "really" is."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2555.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2557.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: 6th Annual Feminist Film Festival", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 7:00 pm  ", "location" : "Second Floor, Women’s Resources Center, 703 S. Wright, Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "Join us for the 6th Anniversary of our Annual Feminist Film Festival, a night of student-made short films (between 5 and 15 minutes in length) screened one night only at the Art Theater Co-Op in downtown Champaign! The Annual Feminist Film Festival a grassroots event that utilizes art and alternative media to bring social issues into the fore. The goal of the festival is to showcase independent film spanning documentary, narrative, and experimental genres in order to explore perspectives often missing from mainstream media and culture. Celebrating it’s 5th anniversary, the festival strives to serve as an inclusive public space for underrepresented artists and filmmakers—particularly women and people of color—to... raise consciousness concerning issues related to gender, race, class, sexuality, and other dimensions of social inequality."}

{"doc_id": "list2602.txt", "event" : "Diversity Calendar: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2623.txt", "event" : "Division of Biomedical Sciences: Phi Gamma Nu Compete For A Cure", "date" : " May 3, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "First and Stadium Play Field Multiplex (Six Pack Fields)", "bio" : "On March 31st, 2010 Pam Stern lost her battle to Lung Cancer. Dustin Stern, her eldest son, felt his mother needed to be honored in a way that represented the way she lived her life – by helping others. That’s when he came up with an idea; after just a month of planning, with the help of Ellen Landgren, and the rest of Phi Gamma Nu, Compete For A Cure was held on May 1st, 2010. With local students participating and enjoying the event, we raised $8,000. Seen as a fantastic achievement, the event continued in 2011 and escalated to higher levels, raising even more money. By the time Dustin Stern graduated the University of Illinois, he and PGN had successfully raised over $40,000."}

{"doc_id": "list2688.txt", "event" : "Education Student Academic Affairs Office Complete Calendar: CSAMES Brown Bag Lecture: The Impact of Migration on Education Outcomes in India", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, on the first floor of the Foreign Languages Building. ", "bio" : "Tanu Kohli (Ph.D. in Global Affairs, Rutgers University), a Lecturer and academic advisor in LAS’s Global Studies program, will speak on “The Impact of Migration on Education Outcomes in India.”  "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2689.txt", "event" : "Education Student Academic Affairs Office Complete Calendar", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm - 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "242 Education Building", "bio" : "When fitting models to data, general assumptions are frequently made automatically without much consideration for their implication on subsequent interpretations. For instance, fitting a standard factor model often presupposes an underlying set of continuous, latent factors. Likewise, when searching for group structure, mixture models (e.g., latent profile analysis, latent class analysis) or cluster analysis are implemented and assume a set of discrete latent classes". Usually, the type of model that is fit to the data is governed by the theoretical notions underpinning the substantive question of interest. In this talk, it is shown that both types of structures can be present and correspond to different subsets of the data. A general strategy is discussed for extracting both class structure and factor structure. Demonstrations are given on a data set of internet habits of collegiate students."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2696.txt", "event" : "Education Student Academic Affairs Office Complete Calendar: College of Education Reception with Indonesian Higher Education Faculty and Administrators", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Education Builiding Room 333", "bio" : "Eight Education faculty and administrators from four public research universities in Indonesia are visiting UIUC as part of a five-year development project funded by USAID. The purpose of the HELM project (Higher Education Leadership and Management) is to expand and strengthen the public higher education sector in Indonesia and, specifically, to assist in strenghtening academic programs that educate the next generation researchers and leaders, affect change in institutional and government policy, and provide outreach and professional development to current and future higher education policy makers, administrators, and faculty."}

{"doc_id": "list2720.txt", "event" : "Education Student Academic Affairs Office Complete Calendar: University Primary School Summer Camps June & July 2015", "date" : " Jun 5, 2015", "time" : " 8:45 am - 5:15 pm  ", "location" : "University Primary School on campus @ 51 Gerty Drive Champaign Il 61820", "bio" : "University Primary School Summer Camp is a weekly camp June 8-July 31 Monday- Friday, 8:45 a.m.-1:00 p.m and/or 1:00 p.m.-5:15 p.m. for children ages 3-12 years old. Campers need not attend University Primary School during the regular school year to attend summer camp. Campers may sign up for single or multiple weeks. Camp experiences for the 3-7 year old group will primarily occur in the school yard gardens and playground where campers will spend time working with plants, water, and new friends. Camp experiences for the 7-12 year old group will include art projects and exploration in sciences. Both groups will have indoor time each day to “cool off” with inside activities including literacy time.  More information: http://education.illinois.edu/ups/documents/2015SummerCampBrochure_JuneandJuly.pdf "}

{"doc_id": "list2869.txt", "event" : "English Department « Department of English, College of LAS, University of Illinois: The Twenty-Fifth Arnold O. Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

{"doc_id": "list2870.txt", "event" : "English Department « Department of English, College of LAS, University of Illinois: "Revolution and Intervention in Libya: Its Implications for the Regional Security in the Middle East post Arab Spring Era"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "tba", "bio" : "Bio: Dr. Ramazan Erdag is a Visiting Scholar for September 2014-May 2015 in ACDIS & CGS University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also affiliated by Faculty Member and Assistant Professor of International Relations at Eskisehir Osmangazi University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2003) in Public Administration from Anadolu University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2008) and Ph.D. (2011) in International Relations from Sakarya University, in Sakarya, Turkey. He focused on Turkey’s new foreign policy in his PhD dissertation.  His areas of expertise are Turkish Foreign Policy, International Security, International Foreign Aids and Regional Security in the Middle East. He teaches the courses as Turkish foreign policy and Turkish political life (Undergraduate level), current issues in international security (Graduate level).  He has several articles and book chapters related to his research areas. His current post-doctoral research topic is based on Regional Security in the Middle East after Arab Spring."}

{"doc_id": "list2880.txt", "event" : "Entrepreneurship at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Make Your Complex Jobs Play Nice: Launching Docker Containers in YARN", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "EnterpriseWorks Atrium", "bio" : "As Hadoop and YARN increase in popularity, more complex jobs get run, and configuration management and maintenance issues soar. How can you make your jobs play nice? {"doc_id": "list2967.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2970.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list2991.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Painting Exhibition", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015 - May 7, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Link Gallery", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list2992.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list3006.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list3080.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 5, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3081.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: KAM Exhibition | With the Grain: Japanese Woodblock Prints from the Postwar Years", "date" : " May 5, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Krannert Art Museum Asian Gallery", "bio" : "Printmaking flourished in Japan during"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3086.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list3114.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list3130.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 11, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list3163.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3164.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: BFA Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015 - May 17, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Krannert Art Museum", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3166.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3167.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list3169.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Yoga | Free and Open to the Public", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Art Museum Classroom Studio B", "bio" : "Krannert Art Museum provides weekly opportunities to practice yoga: one exclusively for museum members and one open to the public."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3173.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3174.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: BFA Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015 - May 17, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Krannert Art Museum", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3176.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3177.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list3244.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list3245.txt", "event" : "Exhibits: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 27, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list16279.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: Charlotte Mattax Moersch, harpsichord", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Foellinger Great Hall", "bio" : "Charlotte Mattax Moersch’s solo recordings include J. S. Bach’s toccatas and partitas and Wilhelm Friedemann Bach’s sonatas. She has collaborated with artists and ensembles including Arleen Auger, Julianne Baird, Laurence Dreyfus, New York’s Grande Bande, and San Francisco’s American Baroque. Her appearances include recitals in the United States and Europe, the Saratoga Festival, the Tage Alter Musik Regensburg, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival, and the Bethlehem Bach Festival. She is currently a professor of harpsichord and the chair of the Harpsichord/Organ Division at the U of I."}

He is also the director of Centre for Urban Planning and Transport Studies at Peking University. He obtained his PhD in planning at University of Groningen, the Netherlands. His research mostly focuses onintegration of transport and land use, TOD, sustainable mobility, urban growth management, compact city and planning for social equality. He has published two books and more than 60 articles in international peer-reviewed journals, such as Urban Studies, Journal of Transport Geography, Environment and Planning A, Land Use Policy, etc.  "}

{"doc_id": "list16322.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list16382.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list16390.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}

{"doc_id": "list16421.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a tea ceremony every Thursday! Please call to reserve your seat along with payment in advance. University of Illinois students pay just $6 per person! Otherwise the fee is $8 per person. A tea ceremony takes approximately an hour. There will be a question and answer period during this time also. We ask that you bring or wear white socks for the ceremony as this represents purity. If you could not wear jeans, that would help with the wear and tear on the tatami mats."}

{"doc_id": "list16442.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: KAM Exhibition | With the Grain: Japanese Woodblock Prints from the Postwar Years", "date" : " May 28, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Krannert Art Museum Asian Gallery", "bio" : "Printmaking flourished in Japan during"}

{"doc_id": "list16443.txt", "event" : "Fine and Applied Arts: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list16449.txt", "event" : "GWS Calendar", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Alma Mater Room, I Hotel", "bio" : "Printmaking flourished in Japan during"}

{"doc_id": "list16454.txt", "event" : "General Events Calendar | ILLINOIS: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list16456.txt", "event" : "General Events Calendar | ILLINOIS: Krannert Center Tour", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Lobby", "bio" : "Meet in the Lobby in front of the Ticket Office to take a peek inside our nooks and crannies and learn more about Krannert Center. Each tour is given by a member of the Krannert Center Student Association, one of our Krannert Center Community Volunteers, or a staff member who will tell you about construction of the building, lead you onto stages, and take you into our production areas."}

{"doc_id": "list16491.txt", "event" : "General Events Calendar | ILLINOIS: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

S. Bach’s toccatas and partitas and Wilhelm Friedemann Bach’s sonatas. She has collaborated with artists and ensembles including Arleen Auger, Julianne Baird, Laurence Dreyfus, New York’s Grande Bande, and San Francisco’s American Baroque. Her appearances include recitals in the United States and Europe, the Saratoga Festival, the Tage Alter Musik Regensburg, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival, and the Bethlehem Bach Festival. She is currently a professor of harpsichord and the chair of the Harpsichord/Organ Division at the U of I."}

She is a member of Tucson Samaritans and No More Deaths, two humanitarian groups based in Tucson for which she provides medical consultation and directs medical education for volunteers. Dr. Price has lived in Tucson for eighteen years and has volunteered with humanitarian groups for thirteen years, since the inception of Tucson Samaritans. After retiring she moved to Arizona from Atlanta, Georgia, where she was in private practice of Medical Oncology for fifteen years followed by practice of general medical and Travel Medicine in an Urgent Care clinic. Dr. Price received her M.D. degree from the University of Tennessee College of Medicine, followed by Internship, Internal Medicine Residency, and Hematology Fellowship at City of Memphis Hospitals of the University of Tennessee College of Medicine. She continued her post-doctorate studies at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, and fellowship in Oncology at Emory University School of Medicine and Winship Cancer Clinic in Atlanta, Georgia."}
