{"doc_id": "list16728.txt", "event" : "General Events Calendar | ILLINOIS: "Revolution and Intervention in Libya: Its Implications for the Regional Security in the Middle East post Arab Spring Era"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "tba", "bio" : "Bio: Dr. Ramazan Erdag is a Visiting Scholar for September 2014-May 2015 in ACDIS & CGS University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also affiliated by Faculty Member and Assistant Professor of International Relations at Eskisehir Osmangazi University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2003) in Public Administration from Anadolu University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2008) and Ph.D. (2011) in International Relations from Sakarya University, in Sakarya, Turkey. He focused on Turkey’s new foreign policy in his PhD dissertation.  His areas of expertise are Turkish Foreign Policy, International Security, International Foreign Aids and Regional Security in the Middle East. He teaches the courses as Turkish foreign policy and Turkish political life (Undergraduate level), current issues in international security (Graduate level).  He has several articles and book chapters related to his research areas. His current post-doctoral research topic is based on Regional Security in the Middle East after Arab Spring."}

{"doc_id": "list16737.txt", "event" : "General Events Calendar | ILLINOIS: ISTC - Sustainable Seminar Series - How sustainable is information technology? Trends, challenges, and opportunities (Webinar)", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm - 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illinois Sustainable Technology Center, One E. Hazelwood Dr., Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "The growing numbers of information technology (IT) devices—and the environmental impacts associated with their manufacture, use, and disposal—are topics that have received much attention in both the media and research communities.  While the environmental footprint of IT devices is indeed significant, each new device generation typically brings substantial operational energy efficiency improvements.  Furthermore, a singular focus on their direct impacts ignores the indirect environmental benefits that IT devices might provide by improving societal energy and resource efficiencies.   A growing body of research suggests that such benefits might be substantial across the economy through such applications as replacing physical goods with digital services, building controls for energy efficiency, and real-time logistics optimization. This presentation will review the life-cycle impacts of IT systems, discuss trends in these impacts as a function of technology progress and growing consumption over time, and highlight the challenges and opportunities associated with managing and reducing the environmental impacts of IT systems moving forward."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list16764.txt", "event" : "Geography and Geographic Information Science (GGIS): CyberGIS Brown Bag - Dr. Pinde Fu - Web GIS: Technologies and Applications", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm - 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "NCSA Room 1040", "bio" : "Title: Web GIS: Technologies and Applications"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list16765.txt", "event" : "Geography and Geographic Information Science (GGIS): Monday, April 27th | Computer Simulation of Large River Evolution", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Digital Computer Lab (DCL), Room 1320", "bio" : "Numerical models provide a valuable framework for integrating understanding of fluvial processes and morphology. Moreover, models represent important tools with which to investigate river responses to environmental change and catchment management, and for aiding the interpretation of alluvial deposits and landforms. This talk aims to examine some recent advances in the development and application of numerical models for simulating river morphodynamics. It will then go on to consider some of the current barriers to progress, and areas requiring further attention in order that such models can be applied effectively to investigate river evolution. In doing so, it will touch upon a range of issues, including: model sensitivity to process parameterisation and boundary conditions; representation of the diversity of river styles seen in nature; long-term coupling of river and floodplain processes; and the challenges associated with modelling river responses to past and future environmental change. The talk focuses in particular on large sand-bed rivers, although many of the issues to be examined are general problems relevant across a wide range of scales."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list16775.txt", "event" : "Germanic Languages and Literatures: The Twenty-Fifth Arnold O. Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

{"doc_id": "list17065.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17067.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17074.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: “Art and Architecture of a Forgotten Kingdom”", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight  Auditorium, Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory St., Urbana", "bio" : "The Hellenistic kingdom of Syracuse in eastern Sicily fell to Rome at the end of the Second Punic War. As a result of this violent conquest many of the achievements of the preceding half-century of peace came to be obscured and even forgotten under Roman domination, and to some extent they have remained so to the present day. The death in the siege of Syracuse of the great scientist and mathematician Archimedes can symbolize the enormous cultural losses of this moment of violent change. The lecture casts light on the innovative and progressive character of earlier Syracusan Hellenistic art through works of sculpture, mosaic, terracotta, and silver, as well as the ambitious architectural programs of the metropolis of Syracuse and other cities within the kingdom, including Akrai and Morgantina."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17079.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17101.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

Lincoln Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "Dr. Norma Price, MD, currently lives in Tucson, Arizona, where her practice of medicine includes volunteering at a South Tucson clinic for the uninsured, volunteering her medical skills addressing needs of migrants in the desert and volunteering in Nogales, Sonora, treating deported migrants. She is a member of Tucson Samaritans and No More Deaths, two humanitarian groups based in Tucson for which she provides medical consultation and directs medical education for volunteers. Dr. Price has lived in Tucson for eighteen years and has volunteered with humanitarian groups for thirteen years, since the inception of Tucson Samaritans. After retiring she moved to Arizona from Atlanta, Georgia, where she was in private practice of Medical Oncology for fifteen years followed by practice of general medical and Travel Medicine in an Urgent Care clinic. Dr. Price received her M.D. degree from the University of Tennessee College of Medicine, followed by Internship, Internal Medicine Residency, and Hematology Fellowship at City of Memphis Hospitals of the University of Tennessee College of Medicine. {"doc_id": "list17128.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Bandung Resurrected: Third World Solidarity, Asian Regionalism, and South Korean Literature", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. Mathews Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "At the historic Bandung Conference in 1955, there was a seat at the table reserved for Japan but none for Japan’s two earliest colonies--Taiwan and Korea. Led by Nehru and profoundly shaped by the history of European colonialisms, the Bandung Conference found no place within its framework for a former colony of an Asian imperial power, now consumed by US-Soviet rivalry. Dead on arrival in the postwar 1950s, the Bandung spirit of anti-colonialism and non-alignment would nevertheless find itself reborn in Korea two decades later as the discourse of Third World Literature. This talk examines the unavowed legacy of the Bandung Conference in guiding South Korean literature’s turn toward political engagement and addresses how the dilemma of Bandung for Japan’s former colony informed the reanimation of Asian regionalism in South Korea at the end of the twentieth century. This reanimation took place in creative tension with the concept of world literature on the one hand and the historical specter of the Greater East Asian Co-prosperity Sphere on the other. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17135.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: iCU China Talks - OIIR Intercultural Dialogue Series "Travelling in China"", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 6:30 pm - 7:30 pm  ", "location" : "Asian American Cultural Center", "bio" : "iCU (now I See what You mean) is an intercultural dialogue series hosted by the OIIR to promote meaningful conversations among domestic and international students on a personal level. {"doc_id": "list17142.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17144.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17152.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}

{"doc_id": "list17153.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Schwarzman Scholarship Information Session", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "Join us to learn about the exciting new Schwarzman Scholarship Program, which is currently holding its inaugural competition! The Schwarzman provides a year of study leading to a Master's degree in Public Policy, Economics and Business, or International Studies at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. All courses are taught in English. Seniors, graduate or professional students, and graduates under the age of 28 are eligible to apply. U.S. and non-U.S. citizens are eligible.  Our informational session is targeted to juniors, seniors, and graduate or professional students, and will provide an overview of the program, including selection criteria, application process, and the benefits provided to the selected scholars.  The priority deadline for the Schwarzman Scholarship is June 1, 2015, and the required campus deadline is August 25, 2015, so now is the time to learn about the program and get answers to your questions!"}

{"doc_id": "list17190.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Manuscripts surviving from the eastern Silk Road site of Dunhuang make possible, among many studies, close explorations of the ways Chinese Buddhists of the ninth and tenth centuries constructed ritual programs. In this talk I will examine three features of those constructions: the natures of the frames by which Buddhist cultic texts--narrative scriptures and incantations--were made the focuses of recitation rites, the borrowings and adaptations of existing materials of which those frames were made, and the understandings of the nature of scriptural language implicit in these practices. I will also consider what these sources can tell us about the history of Buddhism in premodern China more broadly."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17202.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17204.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 2, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17222.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17224.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 3, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17241.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: The Twenty-Fifth Arnold O. Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

{"doc_id": "list17268.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: "Revolution and Intervention in Libya: Its Implications for the Regional Security in the Middle East post Arab Spring Era"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "tba", "bio" : "Bio: Dr. Ramazan Erdag is a Visiting Scholar for September 2014-May 2015 in ACDIS & CGS University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also affiliated by Faculty Member and Assistant Professor of International Relations at Eskisehir Osmangazi University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2003) in Public Administration from Anadolu University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2008) and Ph.D. (2011) in International Relations from Sakarya University, in Sakarya, Turkey. He focused on Turkey’s new foreign policy in his PhD dissertation.  His areas of expertise are Turkish Foreign Policy, International Security, International Foreign Aids and Regional Security in the Middle East. He teaches the courses as Turkish foreign policy and Turkish political life (Undergraduate level), current issues in international security (Graduate level).  He has several articles and book chapters related to his research areas. His current post-doctoral research topic is based on Regional Security in the Middle East after Arab Spring."}

{"doc_id": "list17280.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17285.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Designing a Fulbright Research Proposal", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. {"doc_id": "list17286.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17288.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: UK and Ireland Scholarships Informational Session and Application Workshop", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB 514)", "bio" : "Join us to learn about a group of nationally competitive scholarships that fully fund graduate study in the United Kingdom and Ireland! This informational session and application workshop is targeted to juniors, seniors, and graduate or professional students, and will provide an overview of the Gates Cambridge, Marshall, Mitchell, and Rhodes scholarships.  We will discuss basic eligibility requirements, selection criteria, and the application processes for these awards.  The latter portion of the event is designed to introduce some of the common application components for the scholarships and help participants start to develop content for them.  This is a great opportunity to strategize and get feedback on your ideas for your personal statement and other written portions of the applications.  The priority deadline for the Marshall and Gates Cambridge scholarships is June 1, 2015, and the required campus deadline for many of the UK/Ireland scholarships is August 25, 2015, so now is the time to learn about the programs and get answers to your questions!"}

{"doc_id": "list17295.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17299.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 8, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17313.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17360.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Machine Translation Conference", "date" : " May 10, 2015 - May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Lincoln Room, I-Hotel and Conference Center, 1900 S. First Street, Champaign.", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17362.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17363.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17365.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Illinois-Njala Global Health Symposium", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm - 7:00 pm  ", "location" : "I-Hotel Conference Center, Illini Room B.", "bio" : "The symposium will have opening remarks by Dr. Reitumetse Obakeng Mabokela, who is the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign Vice Provost for International Affairs & Global Strategy. {"doc_id": "list17366.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17437.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 22, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17439.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 22, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list17443.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17480.txt", "event" : "IAS Library Suggests!: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17504.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17507.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Charlotte Mattax Moersch, harpsichord", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Foellinger Great Hall", "bio" : "Charlotte Mattax Moersch’s solo recordings include J. S. Bach’s toccatas and partitas and Wilhelm Friedemann Bach’s sonatas. She has collaborated with artists and ensembles including Arleen Auger, Julianne Baird, Laurence Dreyfus, New York’s Grande Bande, and San Francisco’s American Baroque. Her appearances include recitals in the United States and Europe, the Saratoga Festival, the Tage Alter Musik Regensburg, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival, and the Bethlehem Bach Festival. She is currently a professor of harpsichord and the chair of the Harpsichord/Organ Division at the U of I."}

{"doc_id": "list17510.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17518.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17519.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17573.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17574.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 2, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17611.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17619.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17621.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 8, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17624.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 8, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list17629.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17630.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list17649.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 13, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list17665.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17668.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17669.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list17708.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17709.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 27, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17723.txt", "event" : "IEI and Campus Master: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 30, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17734.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: “Art and Architecture of a Forgotten Kingdom”", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight  Auditorium, Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory St., Urbana", "bio" : "The Hellenistic kingdom of Syracuse in eastern Sicily fell to Rome at the end of the Second Punic War. As a result of this violent conquest many of the achievements of the preceding half-century of peace came to be obscured and even forgotten under Roman domination, and to some extent they have remained so to the present day. The death in the siege of Syracuse of the great scientist and mathematician Archimedes can symbolize the enormous cultural losses of this moment of violent change. The lecture casts light on the innovative and progressive character of earlier Syracusan Hellenistic art through works of sculpture, mosaic, terracotta, and silver, as well as the ambitious architectural programs of the metropolis of Syracuse and other cities within the kingdom, including Akrai and Morgantina."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17741.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Linguistic Seminar - Iftikhar Haider, PhD candidate in Linguistics: "Re-Envisioning Assessment of Inter-language Pragmatic (ILP) Competence through Computer-Mediated Communicative Tasks"", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Abstract: Pragmatics within second language studies is often referred to as Interlanguage Pragmatics (ILP) (Kasper and Rose, 2002). ILP usually examines how non-native speakers develop the communicative language ability in a target language. For immigrants, international students, and business professionals, pragmatic competence is a high-stakes language issue."}

{"doc_id": "list17752.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: 24th Annual Daniel S. Sanders Peace and Social Justice Lecture- Promoting Social Justice and Human Rights for Migrants in the United States", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " 7:30 pm  ", "location" : "Alice Campbell Alumni Center Ballroom, 601 S. Lincoln Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "Dr. Norma Price, MD, currently lives in Tucson, Arizona, where her practice of medicine includes volunteering at a South Tucson clinic for the uninsured, volunteering her medical skills addressing needs of migrants in the desert and volunteering in Nogales, Sonora, treating deported migrants. She is a member of Tucson Samaritans and No More Deaths, two humanitarian groups based in Tucson for which she provides medical consultation and directs medical education for volunteers. Dr. Price has lived in Tucson for eighteen years and has volunteered with humanitarian groups for thirteen years, since the inception of Tucson Samaritans. After retiring she moved to Arizona from Atlanta, Georgia, where she was in private practice of Medical Oncology for fifteen years followed by practice of general medical and Travel Medicine in an Urgent Care clinic. Dr. Price received her M.D. degree from the University of Tennessee College of Medicine, followed by Internship, Internal Medicine Residency, and Hematology Fellowship at City of Memphis Hospitals of the University of Tennessee College of Medicine. She continued her post-doctorate studies at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, and fellowship in Oncology at Emory University School of Medicine and Winship Cancer Clinic in Atlanta, Georgia."}

Wright, Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "NOW's purpose is to take action to bring women into full participation in the mainstream of American society now, exercising all privileges and responsibilities thereof in truly equal partnership with men. This purpose includes, but is not limited to, equal rights and responsibilities in all aspects of citizenship, public service, employment, education, and family life, and it includes freedom from discrimination because of race, ethnic origin, age, marital status, sexual preference/orientation, or parenthood."}

{"doc_id": "list17754.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17757.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17778.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Yoga for Healing I Women on the Move", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 5:30 pm - 6:30 pm  ", "location" : "Second Floor, Women’s Resources Center, 703 S. Wright, Champaign", "bio" : "If you’ve been curious about yoga but hesitant to join an ongoing class, the WRC welcomes you to a yoga for healing class. We will begin with a background of yoga including philosophy, fundamental components of a yoga class, and styles of yoga. We will explore yoga breathing practices and learn some basic yoga poses, with an emphasis on safe movement and effective alignment. Our practice will conclude with a final relaxation period. Yoga for Healing is a safe space, survivor-centered and designed for bodies of all shapes, sizes, and abilities. Dress in clothes that are easy to move around in!"}

Participants will gather at 6:30p.m. at Lincoln Square Mall and will march West towards campus starting at 7p.m. A speak-out will be held on the Engineering Quad after the march (around 8p.m.) where survivors and supporters will be encouraged to share their experiences with the group. {"doc_id": "list17780.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. {"doc_id": "list17782.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17783.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list17785.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AND CULTURES - Chinese Table", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "2050 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Chinese Table is open to students who are learning Chinese at all levels as well as Chinese native speakers who are interested in participating in the conversation. The group meets every Friday during the Fall Semester, except the Friday of Thanksgiving Break (Nov. 28). The final meeting for the semester will be on Friday, May 1."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17786.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Manuscripts surviving from the eastern Silk Road site of Dunhuang make possible, among many studies, close explorations of the ways Chinese Buddhists of the ninth and tenth centuries constructed ritual programs. In this talk I will examine three features of those constructions: the natures of the frames by which Buddhist cultic texts--narrative scriptures and incantations--were made the focuses of recitation rites, the borrowings and adaptations of existing materials of which those frames were made, and the understandings of the nature of scriptural language implicit in these practices. I will also consider what these sources can tell us about the history of Buddhism in premodern China more broadly."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17790.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 2, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17793.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17795.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 3, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17824.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: 6th Annual Feminist Film Festival", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 7:00 pm  ", "location" : "Second Floor, Women’s Resources Center, 703 S. Wright, Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "Join us for the 6th Anniversary of our Annual Feminist Film Festival, a night of student-made short films (between 5 and 15 minutes in length) screened one night only at the Art Theater Co-Op in downtown Champaign! The Annual Feminist Film Festival a grassroots event that utilizes art and alternative media to bring social issues into the fore. The goal of the festival is to showcase independent film spanning documentary, narrative, and experimental genres in order to explore perspectives often missing from mainstream media and culture. Celebrating it’s 5th anniversary, the festival strives to serve as an inclusive public space for underrepresented artists and filmmakers—particularly women and people of color—to... raise consciousness concerning issues related to gender, race, class, sexuality, and other dimensions of social inequality."}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17831.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. {"doc_id": "list17833.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17837.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 10, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
