{"doc_id": "list17866.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: SLCL Spring 2015 Convocation", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " 8:00 pm - 9:00 pm  ", "location" : "Tryon Festival Theatre, Krannert Center for the Performing Arts", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17867.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17868.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list17869.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 17, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17874.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 19, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list17888.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 22, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list17899.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list17900.txt", "event" : "Inclusive Illinois: Diversity at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18094.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18096.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18098.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Charlotte Mattax Moersch, harpsichord", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Foellinger Great Hall", "bio" : "Charlotte Mattax Moersch’s solo recordings include J. S. Bach’s toccatas and partitas and Wilhelm Friedemann Bach’s sonatas. She has collaborated with artists and ensembles including Arleen Auger, Julianne Baird, Laurence Dreyfus, New York’s Grande Bande, and San Francisco’s American Baroque. Her appearances include recitals in the United States and Europe, the Saratoga Festival, the Tage Alter Musik Regensburg, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival, and the Bethlehem Bach Festival. She is currently a professor of harpsichord and the chair of the Harpsichord/Organ Division at the U of I."}

{"doc_id": "list18101.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Meditation Workshop for University of Illinois Students-FULL", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue", "bio" : "Japan House is offering a Meditation Workshop for University of Illinois students. Get away from the stress of finals and graduation by learning the Art of Meditation. Buddhist Monk, Kokai Matsushita will give the demonstration and teach everyone how to become stress-free! Participants are encouraged to bring some kind of seat to use. This can be a firm pillow, large rolled towel, or the traditional zafu. Please wear comfortable clothing (yoga pants, sweatpants etc.) and white socks. Please call with your credit card and reserve your spot because we are limiting the seating to 25 people!"}

{"doc_id": "list18102.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: “Art and Architecture of a Forgotten Kingdom”", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight  Auditorium, Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory St., Urbana", "bio" : "The Hellenistic kingdom of Syracuse in eastern Sicily fell to Rome at the end of the Second Punic War. As a result of this violent conquest many of the achievements of the preceding half-century of peace came to be obscured and even forgotten under Roman domination, and to some extent they have remained so to the present day. The death in the siege of Syracuse of the great scientist and mathematician Archimedes can symbolize the enormous cultural losses of this moment of violent change. The lecture casts light on the innovative and progressive character of earlier Syracusan Hellenistic art through works of sculpture, mosaic, terracotta, and silver, as well as the ambitious architectural programs of the metropolis of Syracuse and other cities within the kingdom, including Akrai and Morgantina."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18118.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Linguistic Seminar - Iftikhar Haider, PhD candidate in Linguistics: "Re-Envisioning Assessment of Inter-language Pragmatic (ILP) Competence through Computer-Mediated Communicative Tasks"", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Abstract: Pragmatics within second language studies is often referred to as Interlanguage Pragmatics (ILP) (Kasper and Rose, 2002). ILP usually examines how non-native speakers develop the communicative language ability in a target language. For immigrants, international students, and business professionals, pragmatic competence is a high-stakes language issue."}

{"doc_id": "list18143.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: 24th Annual Daniel S. Sanders Peace and Social Justice Lecture- Promoting Social Justice and Human Rights for Migrants in the United States", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " 7:30 pm  ", "location" : "Alice Campbell Alumni Center Ballroom, 601 S. Lincoln Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "Dr. Norma Price, MD, currently lives in Tucson, Arizona, where her practice of medicine includes volunteering at a South Tucson clinic for the uninsured, volunteering her medical skills addressing needs of migrants in the desert and volunteering in Nogales, Sonora, treating deported migrants. She is a member of Tucson Samaritans and No More Deaths, two humanitarian groups based in Tucson for which she provides medical consultation and directs medical education for volunteers. Dr. Price has lived in Tucson for eighteen years and has volunteered with humanitarian groups for thirteen years, since the inception of Tucson Samaritans. After retiring she moved to Arizona from Atlanta, Georgia, where she was in private practice of Medical Oncology for fifteen years followed by practice of general medical and Travel Medicine in an Urgent Care clinic. Dr. Price received her M.D. degree from the University of Tennessee College of Medicine, followed by Internship, Internal Medicine Residency, and Hematology Fellowship at City of Memphis Hospitals of the University of Tennessee College of Medicine. She continued her post-doctorate studies at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, and fellowship in Oncology at Emory University School of Medicine and Winship Cancer Clinic in Atlanta, Georgia."}

{"doc_id": "list18150.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18152.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18159.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Bandung Resurrected: Third World Solidarity, Asian Regionalism, and South Korean Literature", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. Mathews Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "At the historic Bandung Conference in 1955, there was a seat at the table reserved for Japan but none for Japan’s two earliest colonies--Taiwan and Korea. Led by Nehru and profoundly shaped by the history of European colonialisms, the Bandung Conference found no place within its framework for a former colony of an Asian imperial power, now consumed by US-Soviet rivalry. Dead on arrival in the postwar 1950s, the Bandung spirit of anti-colonialism and non-alignment would nevertheless find itself reborn in Korea two decades later as the discourse of Third World Literature. This talk examines the unavowed legacy of the Bandung Conference in guiding South Korean literature’s turn toward political engagement and addresses how the dilemma of Bandung for Japan’s former colony informed the reanimation of Asian regionalism in South Korea at the end of the twentieth century. This reanimation took place in creative tension with the concept of world literature on the one hand and the historical specter of the Greater East Asian Co-prosperity Sphere on the other. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18192.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}

{"doc_id": "list18217.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18220.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18236.txt", "event" : "Illinois International", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Manuscripts surviving from the eastern Silk Road site of Dunhuang make possible, among many studies, close explorations of the ways Chinese Buddhists of the ninth and tenth centuries constructed ritual programs. In this talk I will examine three features of those constructions: the natures of the frames by which Buddhist cultic texts--narrative scriptures and incantations--were made the focuses of recitation rites, the borrowings and adaptations of existing materials of which those frames were made, and the understandings of the nature of scriptural language implicit in these practices. I will also consider what these sources can tell us about the history of Buddhism in premodern China more broadly."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18286.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: The Twenty-Fifth Arnold O. Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

{"doc_id": "list18291.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18293.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 5, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18319.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: "Revolution and Intervention in Libya: Its Implications for the Regional Security in the Middle East post Arab Spring Era"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "tba", "bio" : "Bio: Dr. Ramazan Erdag is a Visiting Scholar for September 2014-May 2015 in ACDIS & CGS University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also affiliated by Faculty Member and Assistant Professor of International Relations at Eskisehir Osmangazi University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2003) in Public Administration from Anadolu University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2008) and Ph.D. (2011) in International Relations from Sakarya University, in Sakarya, Turkey. He focused on Turkey’s new foreign policy in his PhD dissertation.  His areas of expertise are Turkish Foreign Policy, International Security, International Foreign Aids and Regional Security in the Middle East. He teaches the courses as Turkish foreign policy and Turkish political life (Undergraduate level), current issues in international security (Graduate level).  He has several articles and book chapters related to his research areas. His current post-doctoral research topic is based on Regional Security in the Middle East after Arab Spring."}

{"doc_id": "list18340.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}

{"doc_id": "list18366.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18369.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18370.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. {"doc_id": "list18427.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}

{"doc_id": "list18433.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18436.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18437.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list18440.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 15, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list18446.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18448.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list18453.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 16, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a tea ceremony every Thursday! Please call to reserve your seat along with payment in advance. University of Illinois students pay just $6 per person! Otherwise the fee is $8 per person. A tea ceremony takes approximately an hour. There will be a question and answer period during this time also. We ask that you bring or wear white socks for the ceremony as this represents purity. If you could not wear jeans, that would help with the wear and tear on the tatami mats."}

{"doc_id": "list18460.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18462.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 17, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18497.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 21, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18506.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 22, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18510.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18511.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 23, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18552.txt", "event" : "Illinois International: Tea Ceremony", "date" : " May 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "2000 S. Lincoln Avenue, Urbana", "bio" : "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan. During the ceremony you will be served a bowl of matcha tea and a Japanese sweet. Reservations are recommended because we sometimes sell out. Call with your credit card information in order to make a reservation. Refunds will be given if you cancel the day before the ceremony (by Wednesday at 3:00 for a Thursday tea, and by Friday at noon before a Saturday tea). You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. Parking is normally metered in the lots to the south and north of us, but is free on weekends. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18576.txt", "event" : "Illinois MBA Program: College of Business Spring Luncheon", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 1:30 pm  ", "location" : "Hyatt Regency Chicago, Grand Ballroom, 151 East Wacker Drive, Chicago, Illinois 60601", "bio" : "Every year since 1960, the College of Business family meets in Chicago to honor faculty and alumni achievements at the annual Spring Luncheon. Please join us as we welcome keynote speaker Shahid Khan, chairman and CEO, Flex-N-Gate; owner, Jacksonville Jaguars; and chairman, Fulham Football Club. The luncheon will recognize the recipients of the Excellence-in-Teaching Awards, the College of Business Appreciation Award, and the College of Business Distinguished Alumnus Award."}

{"doc_id": "list18581.txt", "event" : "Illinois MBA Program: Centennial Celebration in Washington, DC", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 6:00 pm - 8:00 pm  ", "location" : "The Metropolitan Club of the City of Washington, 1700 H Street, NW, Washington, D.C. 20006", "bio" : "Join us for an evening of revelry and connecting with fellow Business alumni in Washington, DC as we celebrate 100 years of Business - and 100 more - at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. As a valued member of the College of Business alumni family, you've helped create our past, and your legacy shapes our present. {"doc_id": "list18623.txt", "event" : "Illinois State Archaeological Survey CalendarIllinois State Archaeological Survey (ISAS) - Illinois Archaeology, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Illinois: Discovering Late Victorian East St. Louis: Urban Archaeology and the New Mississippi River Bridge Project", "date" : " May 17, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "950 North Lombard, Rt 47, Mahomet, Illinois", "bio" : "Between 2009 and 2012, teams of archaeologists from the Illinois State Archaeological Survey (ISAS) conducted large-scale excavations in East St. Louis as part of the New Mississippi River Bridge Project. The recovered artifacts and information, combined with archival research, are yielding new insights into the history of East St. Louis, particularly about the daily lives of working-class individuals and families from the time when the city was a booming transportation and manufacturing hub. The project’s path cut through former residential neighborhoods and remnants of the St. Louis National Stockyards, which lead to the recovery of thousands of artifacts from privies, cisterns, wells, and cellars. This presentation examines the excavation and material culture associated with this Late Victorian East St.Louis working class neighborhood."}

{"doc_id": "list18635.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18637.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18643.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: “Art and Architecture of a Forgotten Kingdom”", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight  Auditorium, Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory St., Urbana", "bio" : "The Hellenistic kingdom of Syracuse in eastern Sicily fell to Rome at the end of the Second Punic War. As a result of this violent conquest many of the achievements of the preceding half-century of peace came to be obscured and even forgotten under Roman domination, and to some extent they have remained so to the present day. The death in the siege of Syracuse of the great scientist and mathematician Archimedes can symbolize the enormous cultural losses of this moment of violent change. The lecture casts light on the innovative and progressive character of earlier Syracusan Hellenistic art through works of sculpture, mosaic, terracotta, and silver, as well as the ambitious architectural programs of the metropolis of Syracuse and other cities within the kingdom, including Akrai and Morgantina."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18679.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Astronomy Colloquium - "Our Warped Universe: Strong Gravitational Lensing in the Dark Energy Survey and Timescapes from the Andes"", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:45 pm  ", "location" : "Astronomy 134", "bio" : "Several clues regarding the acceleration of space-time, dark matter and galaxy evolution in the early universe can be uncovered by studying strong gravitational lenses. The Dark Energy Survey (DES), which started observations in August 2013, is carrying out a wide-field survey of 5,000 square degrees of the Southern Galactic Cap. Much of this sky area has not yet been systematically surveyed, and we expect to discover many new strongly lensed galaxies and quasars. DES has identified 24 strong lens candidate objects (galaxy- and galaxy clusters-scale) in early data, and we have performed spectroscopic follow-up on a subset of these candidates at Gemini South and other telescopes. I will present results from the photometric and spectroscopic analysis of the lensing systems. In addition, we’ll watch the night sky from Cerro Tololo in the Andes (the site of DES operations) through snapshots and timescapes - from mountain life to the Milky Way."}

{"doc_id": "list18693.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18695.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18764.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building", "bio" : "Manuscripts surviving from the eastern Silk Road site of Dunhuang make possible, among many studies, close explorations of the ways Chinese Buddhists of the ninth and tenth centuries constructed ritual programs. In this talk I will examine three features of those constructions: the natures of the frames by which Buddhist cultic texts--narrative scriptures and incantations--were made the focuses of recitation rites, the borrowings and adaptations of existing materials of which those frames were made, and the understandings of the nature of scriptural language implicit in these practices. I will also consider what these sources can tell us about the history of Buddhism in premodern China more broadly."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list18779.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18781.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 2, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18813.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Photoshop Essentials", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "Learn all you need to know to start using Photoshop in this new 2-hour introduction to "Photoshop Essentials."  You'll learn to open, crop (cut away unwanted areas), resize, and straighten your photos, all while learning image navigation (viewing) techniques and how to get around in the Photoshop workspace itself. Common problems (photos that are too dark, too light, too faded, or even too blurry) can often be fixed with some of the Photoshop tools we'll cover. Other tools and techniques allow you to easily "retouch" photos, getting rid of unwanted artifacts such as blemishes, red-eye, etc. You'll also learn how to combine multiple photos into a single image (for example, the front and annotated back of scanned archival photos), as well as add simple text captions to a photo. And of course, we'll also cover saving your finished images in the most appropriate format (and size) for printing, emailing, or posting online."}

Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

{"doc_id": "list18828.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Photoshop CC/CS6: Level 2", "date" : " May 5, 2015 - May 7, 2015", "time" : " 9:00 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "The Level 2 (Intermediate) Photoshop workshop builds on techniques learned in Level 1.  You'll be amazed at what you'll be able to do by combining layers, masks, and channels, easily creating incredibly sophisticated and professional-looking results.  The workshop includes learning more refined techniques for making selections (isolating part of an image), including working in quick-mask mode, using the quick select and magnetic lasso tools, doing free transforms and more.  You'll also learn how to combine multiple images and text into a single composited image.  From among the many other capabilities of Photoshop, we'll also include techniques for working with filters, layer effects (such as drop shadows and embossing), creating layer masks and clipping groups, tinting grayscale images using blending modes, and much more.  While all this may sound complicated, it's actually quite easy to start using these techniques and more, giving your images a much more professional and polished look, whether they are destined for print or for the web."}

{"doc_id": "list18843.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Photoshop CC/CS6: Level 2", "date" : " May 5, 2015 - May 7, 2015", "time" : " 9:00 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "The Level 2 (Intermediate) Photoshop workshop builds on techniques learned in Level 1.  You'll be amazed at what you'll be able to do by combining layers, masks, and channels, easily creating incredibly sophisticated and professional-looking results.  The workshop includes learning more refined techniques for making selections (isolating part of an image), including working in quick-mask mode, using the quick select and magnetic lasso tools, doing free transforms and more.  You'll also learn how to combine multiple images and text into a single composited image.  From among the many other capabilities of Photoshop, we'll also include techniques for working with filters, layer effects (such as drop shadows and embossing), creating layer masks and clipping groups, tinting grayscale images using blending modes, and much more.  While all this may sound complicated, it's actually quite easy to start using these techniques and more, giving your images a much more professional and polished look, whether they are destined for print or for the web."}

{"doc_id": "list18845.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18846.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: InDesign CC/CS6: Level 2", "date" : " May 6, 2015 - May 8, 2015", "time" : " 8:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "Extend your InDesign skills even further by learning to use InDesign's more advanced features effectively. We'll work with nested styles, related styles, applying styles in a sequence, managing style overrides, redefining styles, and even breaking links to styles. With paths (shapes), you'll learn how to use clipping paths to reveal only part of an image, create type outlines, and even create your own Bezier paths. We'll also import layered files (e.g., from Photoshop), merge data into documents, insert footnotes, and create text variables. You'll also learn how to create and manage InDesign libraries, and how to work with long documents, including tables of contents and indices, as well as creating a book document from multiple InDesign files."}

{"doc_id": "list18873.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Acrobat XI Pro: Basic", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 9:00 am - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "UIUC -- location to be announced", "bio" : "This 6 hour course is for individuals with little or no experience using Acrobat XI Pro, but who need to create and share PDF files and PDF Portfolios. Upon successful completion of this course, attendees will open a PDF and explore the interface; create PDF documents in a variety of ways (from a file, using the Print command, from web pages and more); and navigate to and search for specific content in a PDF document (search multiple PDF documents, work with bookmarks, use links).  We will learn how to update PDF documents (manipulate document pages, make basic editing changes to content, add page elements and extract content); optimize and convert PDF documents to other formats. Finally we will look at how to initiate a review of a PDF and how to optimize and convert a PDF to other file formats."}

{"doc_id": "list18907.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18911.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18912.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list18935.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Dreamweaver CC: Level 2", "date" : " May 11, 2015 - May 13, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "The Dreamweaver Level 2 workshop explores CSS in much greater depth, and also covers a number of Dreamweaver "power features" that add greatly to the richness and productivity of the program. You'll learn to effectively control the layout and format of your web pages on multiple devices (desktop, tablet, and/or phone) with Dreamweaver’s powerful CSS-based “fluid grid layout” tools. You'll use CSS to format your pages, create CSS “rollover” transitions, and create web forms to collect and validate data (for example, double-checking email address entries). You'll also include audio and video files on your pages, as well as integrating Photoshop files into web pages, with automatic conversion to browser-compatible formats. Finally, you'll preview and test your web site for browser compatibility, CSS validation, basic accessibility features, and much more."}

{"doc_id": "list18950.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Outlook 2013: People & Tasks", "date" : " May 12, 2015", "time" : " 10:00 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "UIUC -- location to be announced", "bio" : "Creating a contact in Outlook 2013 can save you time when sending an email message and using Lync. Once you've entered a name as a contact, you can add business or personal information such as phone numbers and addresses. In this 2-hour short course you will learn how to work in the People window to add a new contact (manually and from a received email message); change contacts view; use color categories to organize your contacts; search for a contact; and print a contacts list. {"doc_id": "list18951.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Illustrator CC/CS6: Level 2", "date" : " May 12, 2015 - May 14, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "Discover some of Illustrator’s more advanced capabilities for creating even more sophisticated and striking results. You’ll learn to create custom shapes and “compound paths” using simple shapes as a starting point, to create perspective drawings using Illustrator’s Perspective Grid tool, and to use Illustrator's newly enhanced "image trace" feature to convert (simple) photographs into fully-scalable Illustrator paths. You'll also work with colors, swatches, Pantone libraries, and color groups, create custom brushes, and use Illustrator's "Live Paint" feature, as well as painting objects with fills, strokes, and gradients.  Other topics include advanced type formatting options, applying meshes, patterns, transparency, and blending modes to objects, as well as working with graphics styles and effects, masks, symbol sets, symbolism tools, and more."}

{"doc_id": "list18972.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club", "date" : " May 13, 2015", "time" : " 10:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "UIUC -- location to be announced", "bio" : "In this 1.5-hour overview, we will explore the new look and feel of Lync 2013 including the Quick Lync bar which provides more functionality with a cleaner look. Working with contacts is easier than ever using the new Favorites group to build a list of people you contact the most often. We will tour the ways to view your contacts list including “New” to see a list of people who have asked to be included on your Contacts list. We’ll see where the Chat Rooms feature has replaced the Activity Feed view. The New Tabbed Conversation feature is next, where you can keep all your calls, instant messages, and chat rooms in one conversation window. Interface changes also include icons at the bottom of the conversation window which let you quickly add others to an IM or upgrade to an audio call, a video call, or a presentation with file-sharing and web conferencing tools (whiteboard, meeting notes, shared notebooks, and attachments). We will practice making calls and sending messages using this new interface. Lastly, we will try out the new Video features including the new Gallery View, where you can automatically see everyone in a video conference."}

{"doc_id": "list18974.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Lync 2013: Audio/Video/Web Conferencing", "date" : " May 13, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "UIUC -- location to be announced", "bio" : "This two hour workshop will demonstrate how easy it is to set up and attend an online meeting using Lync 2013. Meeting schedulers will learn how to escalate an instant message or phone conversation into an audio or video conference; schedule an online meeting in Outlook 2010 or 2013 using default options; customize advanced meeting options for unique meeting requirements; how to create a recording of a meeting; and schedule a meeting on behalf of another. Different meeting roles (attendee versus presenter) will be discussed; and we will learn how to use a virtual waiting room known as a “lobby” for control over who attends a meeting. In addition, we’ll spend a few minutes looking at the new expanded meeting controls including the Share menu which gives you access to all presentable content in one place, such as Desktop, PowerPoint presentations, Poll, Whiteboard, and OneNote. We’ll look at the new meeting layouts for different types of meetings. We will learn about Lync Web App which allows PC and Mac users to join a Lync Meeting from within a web browser while delivering a full Lync Meeting experience. Finally, the use of Lync Mobile clients will be discussed."}

{"doc_id": "list18980.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list18984.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Illustrator CC/CS6: Level 2", "date" : " May 12, 2015 - May 14, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illini Hall, Suite 26 (lower level; NW corner of John & Wright Streets, Champaign)", "bio" : "Discover some of Illustrator’s more advanced capabilities for creating even more sophisticated and striking results. You’ll learn to create custom shapes and “compound paths” using simple shapes as a starting point, to create perspective drawings using Illustrator’s Perspective Grid tool, and to use Illustrator's newly enhanced "image trace" feature to convert (simple) photographs into fully-scalable Illustrator paths. You'll also work with colors, swatches, Pantone libraries, and color groups, create custom brushes, and use Illustrator's "Live Paint" feature, as well as painting objects with fills, strokes, and gradients.  Other topics include advanced type formatting options, applying meshes, patterns, transparency, and blending modes to objects, as well as working with graphics styles and effects, masks, symbol sets, symbolism tools, and more."}

{"doc_id": "list18987.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list18988.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: KAM Exhibition | Bachelor of Fine Arts Exhibition", "date" : " May 14, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "KAM Main Level, East Gallery, Rosann Gelvin Noel Gallery and Annex, Light Court Gallery", "bio" : "The annual exhibition of works by graduates from the School of Art + Design's Bachelor of Fine Arts programs represents the full range of contemporary art and design practices. Exhibiting artists have worked rigorously to develop individual visions and to solve complex problems with cross-disciplinary teams. As you will see in the works on display, they have learned trusted methods and forms, but have also challenged conventions. Emerging technologies and ideas can be seen across painting and typography, product design and sculpture. This exhibition is but a sample of their efforts and achievements to represent, reflect and reimagine the world around us."}

{"doc_id": "list19056.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list19058.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Excel 2013: Level 2", "date" : " May 18, 2015 - May 20, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "UIUC -- location to be announced", "bio" : "In this 6-hour Excel 2013 Level 2 course, you will create advanced formulas; analyze data with logical and lookup functions; organize worksheet data with tables; visualize data by using charts; and analyze data with PivotTables, slicers, and PivotCharts.  This course is about one simple idea: asking your data questions and using Excel 2013 to find the answers."}

{"doc_id": "list19059.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 20, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
