{"doc_id": "list19061.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: OneNote 2013: Basics", "date" : " May 20, 2015", "time" : " 9:00 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "UIUC -- location to be announced", "bio" : "In this 3 hour course, you will develop digital note-taking, note-collaboration, and note-synchronizing skills with OneNote 2013. Topics covered will include: exploring the structure of a OneNote notebook; adding content to and organize a OneNote notebook; managing OneNote notebooks, history, and backups; working with Excel spreadsheets and embedded files; sharing and collaborate with notebooks; and finalizing a notebook."}

{"doc_id": "list19065.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list19067.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

In this 2-hour hands-on instructor led workshop, attendees will learn how to start and sign on to Lync, learn how to navigate the Lync 2011 program window, learn about presence (availability status), add contacts to their contact list, and find help resources."}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list19079.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Mindful Meditation at the Spurlock Museum", "date" : " May 22, 2015", "time" : " 11:30 am - 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Knight Audtiorium, Spurlock Museum", "bio" : "Present-moment awareness can be elusive and it can be easy to become distracted or lost in thought.  Through the training and practice of mindful meditation, one can discover a calm and more fully appreciate the gift of each day. Mary Wolters from Green Yoga Spa will lead free, 30-minute mindful meditation sessions in the Knight Auditorium at the Spurlock Museum.  No registration is necessary, participants may attend as many or few sessions as they like.  The series continues each Friday, 11:30 - 12:00, through May 8th.  Metered parking is typically readily available around the museum. "}

{"doc_id": "list19135.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: East Meets Midwest: The Dawn of the China-Illinois Educational Exchange", "date" : " Jan 20, 2015 - Jun 21, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "For over a century, the University of Illinois has played a leading role in the promotion of educational exchange with China. UI President Edmund James was a leader in the movement to open US universities to Chinese students in 1906, when US policy toward China was very restrictive in this area. This exhibit tells the story of how James’s vision led the University of Illinois to become one of the most significant destinations for Chinese students during the early decades of the 20th century. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}

{"doc_id": "list19138.txt", "event" : "Indonesian Students Club: Exhibit: South Asian Seams: Quilts from India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh", "date" : " May 29, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "Spurlock Museum, 600 S. Gregory, Urbana, IL", "bio" : "Quiltmaking is an integral and vital part of South Asian culture. Much the same as here in the West, quilts serve both functional and symbolic purposes. They provide warmth as well as a comfortable place to sit; and they also commemorate special occasions and tell the stories of the lives of their makers. The seams that bring together different pieces of fabric in a quilt also represent the seams that bring together this vast region—its people, its cultures, and its shared tradition of extraordinary textiles. The exhibit will be on display Tuesday, February 17–Saturday, August 1. The exhibit is open Museum hours: Tuesdays 12-5, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays 9-5, Saturdays 10-4, and Sundays 12-4."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list19242.txt", "event" : "International Programs and Studies: CSAMES Brown Bag Lecture: Impact of Migration on Education Outcomes in India", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm - 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, 1080 Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. { "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list19245.txt", "event" : "International Programs and Studies: Bandung Resurrected: Third World Solidarity, Asian Regionalism, and South Korean Literature", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. Mathews Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "At the historic Bandung Conference in 1955, there was a seat at the table reserved for Japan but none for Japan’s two earliest colonies--Taiwan and Korea. Led by Nehru and profoundly shaped by the history of European colonialisms, the Bandung Conference found no place within its framework for a former colony of an Asian imperial power, now consumed by US-Soviet rivalry. Dead on arrival in the postwar 1950s, the Bandung spirit of anti-colonialism and non-alignment would nevertheless find itself reborn in Korea two decades later as the discourse of Third World Literature. This talk examines the unavowed legacy of the Bandung Conference in guiding South Korean literature’s turn toward political engagement and addresses how the dilemma of Bandung for Japan’s former colony informed the reanimation of Asian regionalism in South Korea at the end of the twentieth century. This reanimation took place in creative tension with the concept of world literature on the one hand and the historical specter of the Greater East Asian Co-prosperity Sphere on the other. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list19250.txt", "event" : "International Programs and Studies: Heaven Admits No Slaves", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "Room 106 English Building", "bio" : "Heaven Admits No Slaves is a love story set against the background of the Ukrainian Revolution that began on the Euromaidan in late 2013. Svitlana and Askold, as well as their friends, are transformed into revolutionaries as millions of Ukrainians take to the streets to protest corruption and to envision a new civil society. But they soon find themselves in a conflict much darker: an undeclared war with Russia on Ukraine’s eastern border. The shooting of the film is still in progress."}

{"doc_id": "list19260.txt", "event" : "International Programs and Studies: "Revolution and Intervention in Libya: Its Implications for the Regional Security in the Middle East post Arab Spring Era"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "tba", "bio" : "Bio: Dr. Ramazan Erdag is a Visiting Scholar for September 2014-May 2015 in ACDIS & CGS University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also affiliated by Faculty Member and Assistant Professor of International Relations at Eskisehir Osmangazi University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2003) in Public Administration from Anadolu University in Eskisehir, Turkey. He holds B.A. (2008) and Ph.D. (2011) in International Relations from Sakarya University, in Sakarya, Turkey. He focused on Turkey’s new foreign policy in his PhD dissertation.  His areas of expertise are Turkish Foreign Policy, International Security, International Foreign Aids and Regional Security in the Middle East. He teaches the courses as Turkish foreign policy and Turkish political life (Undergraduate level), current issues in international security (Graduate level).  He has several articles and book chapters related to his research areas. His current post-doctoral research topic is based on Regional Security in the Middle East after Arab Spring."}

{"doc_id": "list19275.txt", "event" : "International Student and Scholar Services: Bandung Resurrected: Third World Solidarity, Asian Regionalism, and South Korean Literature", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Lucy Ellis Lounge, Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. Mathews Ave., Urbana", "bio" : "At the historic Bandung Conference in 1955, there was a seat at the table reserved for Japan but none for Japan’s two earliest colonies--Taiwan and Korea. Led by Nehru and profoundly shaped by the history of European colonialisms, the Bandung Conference found no place within its framework for a former colony of an Asian imperial power, now consumed by US-Soviet rivalry. Dead on arrival in the postwar 1950s, the Bandung spirit of anti-colonialism and non-alignment would nevertheless find itself reborn in Korea two decades later as the discourse of Third World Literature. This talk examines the unavowed legacy of the Bandung Conference in guiding South Korean literature’s turn toward political engagement and addresses how the dilemma of Bandung for Japan’s former colony informed the reanimation of Asian regionalism in South Korea at the end of the twentieth century. This reanimation took place in creative tension with the concept of world literature on the one hand and the historical specter of the Greater East Asian Co-prosperity Sphere on the other. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list19547.txt", "event" : "Library Calendar | University Library - University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign: Poplin and Paper: Four Centuries of Fashion in Print", "date" : " May 18, 2015 - Sep 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "346 Main Library, Monday through Friday", "bio" : "The term “fashion plate” is layered with meanings. It is a portrait depicting not an individual but rather an outfit that a clothier can supply. It is also frequently used to describe someone who wears the latest styles. But a plate is also a printing term, describing an illustration transferred to paper during the printing process."}

{"doc_id": "list19620.txt", "event" : "Library Calendar | University Library - University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign: Poplin and Paper: Four Centuries of Fashion in Print", "date" : " May 18, 2015 - Sep 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "346 Main Library, Monday through Friday", "bio" : "The term “fashion plate” is layered with meanings. {"doc_id": "list19800.txt", "event" : "Library Calendar | University Library - University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign: Poplin and Paper: Four Centuries of Fashion in Print", "date" : " May 18, 2015 - Sep 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "346 Main Library, Monday through Friday", "bio" : "The term “fashion plate” is layered with meanings. {"doc_id": "list19949.txt", "event" : "Library Calendar | University Library - University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign: Poplin and Paper: Four Centuries of Fashion in Print", "date" : " May 18, 2015 - Sep 9, 2015", "time" : " All Day", "location" : "346 Main Library, Monday through Friday", "bio" : "The term “fashion plate” is layered with meanings. It is a portrait depicting not an individual but rather an outfit that a clothier can supply. It is also frequently used to describe someone who wears the latest styles. But a plate is also a printing term, describing an illustration transferred to paper during the printing process."}

{"doc_id": "list19993.txt", "event" : "MCB Calendar: Microbiology Seminar: Dr. Dennis Thiele, Duke University -- "Copper as an anti-microbial weapon in the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans"", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "Charles G. {"doc_id": "list19994.txt", "event" : "MCB Calendar: Biochemistry Seminar: Dr. Lynette Cegelski (Stanford University), "Structure, Function, and Inhibition of Bacterial Cell Walls and Biofilms: Lessons from Small Molecules and a Big Magnet"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Charles G. Miller Auditorium (B102 CLSL)", "bio" : "ABSTRACT:  The bacterial cell wall is essential to cell viability and is a major target of antibiotics. Beyond the cell wall and the cell surface, bacteria secrete proteins and polysaccharides to enmesh themselves in a protective biofilm matrix that enhances bacterial resistance to antibiotics. As heterogeneous, insoluble polymeric matrices, cell walls and biofilms pose a challenge to analysis by conventional methods. We are developing new approaches to dissect composition in cell walls and whole cells and to transform vague biofilm descriptors into quantitative parameters of chemical and molecular composition. In our drug discovery efforts, we have identified small-molecule biofilm inhibitors and are examining their influence on biofilm formation and on pathogenesis in vivo. I will discuss these and our emerging discoveries inspired by the urgent need for new strategies to treat infectious diseases, integrating bacteriology, biochemistry, and whole-cell NMR, specifically targeting E. coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Vibrio cholerae."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list20166.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: ICMT Seminar: "The Puzzle of the Coulomb Energy in the Cuprates, Implications of Ellipsometric Measurements"", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "ESB 190", "bio" : "Some years ago, one of us [AJL PNAS 1999], proposed a scenario for cuprate superconductity in which the energy saving driving the transition is of Coulomb Energy (CE) in the long-wavelength, midinfrared frequency range. With minimal assumptions, this conjecture can be tested by measuring the optical loss function. The impetus for the present experimental and theoretical collaborative effort, was the observation, in the analysis of ellipsometric data on Bi-2223, of an anomaly in the integrated loss function at T1>Tc in the mid-infrared (MIR) range, and in the full frequency range (FR), and subsequently other data have been analyzed. The purpose is to examine the behavior, in the long-wavelength limit, of the CE of these HTSC, and the changes of the Loss Function at Tc and near Tc. "}

{"doc_id": "list20167.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Materials Science and Engineering Colloquium", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "100 Materials Science and Engineering Building", "bio" : ""Billions and billions of molecules: Exploring chemical space" - Many of the challenges of the twenty-first century are related to molecular processes such as the generation, transmission, and storage of clean energy, water purification and desalination. These transformations require a next generation of more efficient and ecologically-friendly materials. In the life sciences, we face similar challenges, for example drug-resistant bacterial strains require novel antibiotics. One of the paradigm shifts that the theoretical and experimental chemists needs to embrace is that of accelerated molecular discovery: The design cycles need to be sped up by the constant interaction of theoreticians and experimentalists, the use of high-throughput computational techniques, tools from machine learning and big data, and the development of public materials databases. I will describe three projects from my research group that aim to operate in this accelerated design cycle. First, I will describe our efforts on the Harvard Clean Energy Project (http://cleanenergy.harvard.edu), a search for materials for organic solar cells. I will continue by talking about our work on developing organic molecules for energy storage in flow batteries. Finally, I will describe our work towards the discovery of novel molecules for organic light-emitting diodes."}

{"doc_id": "list20174.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Physics Colloquium: "Designing Superconductivity: Manipulating Interactions in Arrays of Superconducting Islands"", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "141 Loomis", "bio" : "One of the most fundamental questions in physics is how the macroscopic properties of matter emerge from microscopic constituents. Often, complex electronic correlations at the micro-scale act to create remarkable macroscopic materials properties, such as superconductivity and ferromagnetism. But the parameters relevant to understanding and manipulating these correlations are difficult to access. In this talk, I will discuss a "bottom-up" approach to studying collective effects in matter via nanostructured arrays of superconducting islands. We fabricate large arrays of superconducting islands patterned on normal metal films; by changing the size and configuration of the islands, we can to tune the parameters relevant to 2D superconductivity, such as disorder, dissipation, and phase separation. I will discuss electrical transport measurements of these systems, including characterization of the superconducting transitions, vortex dynamics in finite magnetic-fields, and evidence that the system approaches an unusual metallic ground state as the island spacing is increased. I will also discuss the mechanism behind the suppression of superconductivity in individual granular islands, even at large diameters."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list20176.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Prof. Dorothea Fiedler, Princeton University, "The Inositol Pyrophosphates Provide a Link Between Signaling and Metabolism"", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "116 Roger Adams Lab", "bio" : "link for robots only"}

{"doc_id": "list20177.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Condensed Matter Seminar: "Electronically-Induced Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped Cuprates and Iron Pnictides."", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "ESB 190", "bio" : "The relationship between electronic nematicity -- i.e. tetragonal symmetry-breaking induced by electronic rather than lattice degrees of freedom -- and unconventional superconductivity remains a widely investigated topic. The prime experimental tool to probe these nematic phases in cooper-based and iron-based superconductors is the in-plane resistivity anisotropy $\Delta\rho=\rho_{xx}-\rho_{yy}$, which, by symmetry arguments, must be proportional to the nematic order parameter $\eta$ near the nematic transition,  $\Delta\rho = C \eta$. In order to advance our understanding of the mechanisms and properties of the nematic phases, it is necessary however to go beyond phenomenological models and relate the proportionality constant $C$ to the collective behavior of the nematic Fermi fluid. In this work, we employ a Boltzmann equation approach to study how anisotropic fluctuations present in both underdoped  iron pnictides and cuprates are manifested in $\Delta\rho$, and, more specifically, in the proportionality constant $C$. We find in general two contributions to the resistivity anisotropy: one arising from the anisotropic scattering of the electrons by the actual fluctuations, which is dominant at higher temperatures, and a second one due to the anisotropic Fermi-velocity renormalization promoted by virtual fluctuations, which is dominant at lower temperatures. For the case of underdoped iron pnictides, for which anisotropic magnetic fluctuations are the lowest-energy excitations, we find that the two contributions yield generally the same sign of $C$, including its sign-change for sufficiently hole-doping. However, they differ in their dependence on the temperature and on the magnetic correlation length, which allows one to distinguish these two contributions experimentally. For the underdoped cuprates, not only anisotropic magnetic fluctuations, but also low-energy anisotropic charge fluctuations are present over a wide doping regime. We show that they give antagonistic contributions to the resistivity anisotropy, i.e. scattering of electrons by magnetic and charge fluctuations promote different signs for the proportionality constant $C$. We argue that these results qualitatively agree with the doping dependence of the resistivity anisotropy measured in detwinned orthorhombic YBCO, and discuss how they can be identified in strained tetragonal cuprates."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20178.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Biological Physics Seminar (CPLC): "May the force be with the Ring, or not - bacterial cytokinesis in superresolution"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "144 Loomis", "bio" : "During cytokinesis, a mechanical force constricts the cell envelope against an internal turgor pressure. In bacteria, this force is attributed to the essential 'divisome' machinery. The most conserved divisome component is the FtsZ ring, or Z-ring, which comprises protofilaments of the bacterial tubulin homolog and GTPase, FtsZ. Although the Z-ring has been a prevailing candidate for constrictive force generation, proposed force generation mechanisms have been difficult to test in vivo due to the essentiality of FtsZ, the limited ability to spatially resolve the Z-ring structure in small bacterial cells, and the lack of sensitive methods to monitor Z-ring contraction and the rate of septum closure during cytokinesis. We applied quantitative single-molecule based superresolution imaging with other biophysical techniques and genetic manipulations to examine the structure of the Z-ring and its contraction during cytokinesis. Our results challenge the FtsZ-centric view of constrictive force generation in bacteria, and suggest that FtsZ should be viewed as a key structural scaffold, regulator, or mediator rather than as a major force generator."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20179.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Prof. Sunney Xie, Harvard University, "Life at the Single Molecule Level: From Single Molecule Enzymology to Single Cell Genomics"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "116 RAL", "bio" : "B 102 CLSL"}

{"doc_id": "list20180.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: CPLC/Biophysics Graduate Student/Postdoc Symposium", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 8:30 am  ", "location" : "Beckman Institute, Room 1005", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20181.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Materials Science and Engineering Special Seminar", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 8:30 am  ", "location" : "119 Materials Science and Engineering Building", "bio" : ""The competition of surface tension and elasticity drives new phenomena in soft solids" - The classic models of solid mechanics were developed to describe the behavior of stiff materials. However, the rise of polymers, mechanobiology, soft robotics, and flexible electronics have driven broad interest in the mechanics of ‘soft’ solids. Our recent experiments demonstrate that the mechanics of soft interfaces are qualitatively changed when the characteristic length-scale of deformation falls below a material-dependent scale. In this regime, classic theories of wetting (Young-Dupre), adhesion (JKR), and composites (Eshelby) fail dramatically. However, we are able to capture the essential features of these phenomena with linear-elastic analytical models that properly account for solid surface tension. We exploit the coupling of elasticity and surface tension to design new materials and devices. So far, we have created solid-liquid composites with surprising mechanical properties and devices that passively transport liquid droplets. Currently, we are extending these concepts to develop new approaches to the self-assembly of photonic band gap materials."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20182.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: The Secrets in their landscapes: Elucidating conformational preferences of proteins for design of allosteric modulators", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "3269 Beckman", "bio" : "Mechanistic understanding of the large scale conformational transformations coupled with activation of key signaling proteins such as G-Protein Coupled Receptors (GPCRs) and Kinases are of enormous importance not only for the development of therapeutic drugs for the treatment of diseases but also for the understanding of stress-related (due to climate change) signaling in plants. In principle, the nature of conformational transition could be modeled in silico via atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, although this is very challenging due to the long activation timescales (in milliseconds). We employ a computational paradigm that couples cloud computing, transition pathway techniques and Markov State Model (MSM) based novel sampling algorithms for mapping the conformational landscape of proteins. These computations provide the thermodynamics and kinetics of their activation for the first time, and help identify key structural intermediates and novel allosteric sites for targeted design."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list20189.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Prof. Kurt Zilm, Yale, "Structure and Dynamics in Proteins as Viewed by Solids NMR: Water, Disordered States, and Prions"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "B102 CLSL", "bio" : "B102 CLSL"}

{"doc_id": "list20190.txt", "event" : "Materials Research Laboratory: Physics Colloquium: "Atomic-scale Antagonism between d-Symmetry Cooper Pairs and d-Symmetry Density Waves in Cuprate Superconductors"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "141 Loomis", "bio" : "            A central issue of research into the high temperature superconducting copper-oxides is to understand the nature of the pseudogap phase and its relationship to the d-symmetry superconductivity. Using our recently developed technique of sub-lattice phase-resolved electronic structure visualization within each CuO2 unit-cell [1], we found that the density wave observed in the cuprate pseudogap regime, itself exhibits d-symmetry [2]. Although long predicted, such an unconventional density-wave state has not previously been observed in any condensed matter system. Our simultaneous visualizations of both real-space and momentum-space electronic structure across the cuprate phase diagram then revealed that the transition of Fermi surface topology from the mysterious “Fermi arc” to conventional Fermi surface occurs simultaneously with the disappearance of the d-symmetry density wave [3]. Taken together these results provide key information on the microscopic mechanism of the d-symmetry density wave state, and on the antagonism between it and the d-symmetry Cooper pairing."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list20272.txt", "event" : "Medieval Studies: Charlotte Mattax Moersch, harpsichord", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Foellinger Great Hall", "bio" : "Charlotte Mattax Moersch’s solo recordings include J. S. Bach’s toccatas and partitas and Wilhelm Friedemann Bach’s sonatas. She has collaborated with artists and ensembles including Arleen Auger, Julianne Baird, Laurence Dreyfus, New York’s Grande Bande, and San Francisco’s American Baroque. Her appearances include recitals in the United States and Europe, the Saratoga Festival, the Tage Alter Musik Regensburg, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival, and the Bethlehem Bach Festival. She is currently a professor of harpsichord and the chair of the Harpsichord/Organ Division at the U of I."}

{"doc_id": "list20461.txt", "event" : "Events | National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois: The Twenty-Fifth Arnold O. Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

She is a member of Tucson Samaritans and No More Deaths, two humanitarian groups based in Tucson for which she provides medical consultation and directs medical education for volunteers. Dr. Price has lived in Tucson for eighteen years and has volunteered with humanitarian groups for thirteen years, since the inception of Tucson Samaritans. After retiring she moved to Arizona from Atlanta, Georgia, where she was in private practice of Medical Oncology for fifteen years followed by practice of general medical and Travel Medicine in an Urgent Care clinic. Dr. Price received her M.D. degree from the University of Tennessee College of Medicine, followed by Internship, Internal Medicine Residency, and Hematology Fellowship at City of Memphis Hospitals of the University of Tennessee College of Medicine. She continued her post-doctorate studies at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, and fellowship in Oncology at Emory University School of Medicine and Winship Cancer Clinic in Atlanta, Georgia."}

{"doc_id": "list20571.txt", "event" : "Neuroscience Program: Biochemistry Seminar: Dr. Lynette Cegelski (Stanford University), "Structure, Function, and Inhibition of Bacterial Cell Walls and Biofilms: Lessons from Small Molecules and a Big Magnet"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Charles G. Miller Auditorium (B102 CLSL)", "bio" : "ABSTRACT:  The bacterial cell wall is essential to cell viability and is a major target of antibiotics. Beyond the cell wall and the cell surface, bacteria secrete proteins and polysaccharides to enmesh themselves in a protective biofilm matrix that enhances bacterial resistance to antibiotics. As heterogeneous, insoluble polymeric matrices, cell walls and biofilms pose a challenge to analysis by conventional methods. We are developing new approaches to dissect composition in cell walls and whole cells and to transform vague biofilm descriptors into quantitative parameters of chemical and molecular composition. In our drug discovery efforts, we have identified small-molecule biofilm inhibitors and are examining their influence on biofilm formation and on pathogenesis in vivo. I will discuss these and our emerging discoveries inspired by the urgent need for new strategies to treat infectious diseases, integrating bacteriology, biochemistry, and whole-cell NMR, specifically targeting E. coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Vibrio cholerae."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list20847.txt", "event" : "Parents Programs Calendar: Charlotte Mattax Moersch, harpsichord", "date" : " Apr 26, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm  ", "location" : "Krannert Center, Foellinger Great Hall", "bio" : "Charlotte Mattax Moersch’s solo recordings include J. S. Bach’s toccatas and partitas and Wilhelm Friedemann Bach’s sonatas. She has collaborated with artists and ensembles including Arleen Auger, Julianne Baird, Laurence Dreyfus, New York’s Grande Bande, and San Francisco’s American Baroque. Her appearances include recitals in the United States and Europe, the Saratoga Festival, the Tage Alter Musik Regensburg, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival, and the Bethlehem Bach Festival. She is currently a professor of harpsichord and the chair of the Harpsichord/Organ Division at the U of I."}

{"doc_id": "list20977.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Astronomy Colloquium - "Our Warped Universe: Strong Gravitational Lensing in the Dark Energy Survey and Timescapes from the Andes"", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:45 pm  ", "location" : "Astronomy 134", "bio" : "Several clues regarding the acceleration of space-time, dark matter and galaxy evolution in the early universe can be uncovered by studying strong gravitational lenses. The Dark Energy Survey (DES), which started observations in August 2013, is carrying out a wide-field survey of 5,000 square degrees of the Southern Galactic Cap. Much of this sky area has not yet been systematically surveyed, and we expect to discover many new strongly lensed galaxies and quasars. DES has identified 24 strong lens candidate objects (galaxy- and galaxy clusters-scale) in early data, and we have performed spectroscopic follow-up on a subset of these candidates at Gemini South and other telescopes. I will present results from the photometric and spectroscopic analysis of the lensing systems. In addition, we’ll watch the night sky from Cerro Tololo in the Andes (the site of DES operations) through snapshots and timescapes - from mountain life to the Milky Way."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20978.txt", "event" : "CPLC Events :: Department of Physics at the U of I: Biological Physics Seminar (CPLC): "May the force be with the Ring, or not - bacterial cytokinesis in superresolution"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "144 Loomis", "bio" : "During cytokinesis, a mechanical force constricts the cell envelope against an internal turgor pressure. In bacteria, this force is attributed to the essential 'divisome' machinery. The most conserved divisome component is the FtsZ ring, or Z-ring, which comprises protofilaments of the bacterial tubulin homolog and GTPase, FtsZ. Although the Z-ring has been a prevailing candidate for constrictive force generation, proposed force generation mechanisms have been difficult to test in vivo due to the essentiality of FtsZ, the limited ability to spatially resolve the Z-ring structure in small bacterial cells, and the lack of sensitive methods to monitor Z-ring contraction and the rate of septum closure during cytokinesis. We applied quantitative single-molecule based superresolution imaging with other biophysical techniques and genetic manipulations to examine the structure of the Z-ring and its contraction during cytokinesis. Our results challenge the FtsZ-centric view of constrictive force generation in bacteria, and suggest that FtsZ should be viewed as a key structural scaffold, regulator, or mediator rather than as a major force generator."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20979.txt", "event" : "CPLC Events :: Department of Physics at the U of I: CPLC/Biophysics Graduate Student/Postdoc Symposium", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 8:30 am  ", "location" : "Beckman Institute, Room 1005", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20980.txt", "event" : "CPLC Events :: Department of Physics at the U of I: The Secrets in their landscapes: Elucidating conformational preferences of proteins for design of allosteric modulators", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "3269 Beckman", "bio" : "Mechanistic understanding of the large scale conformational transformations coupled with activation of key signaling proteins such as G-Protein Coupled Receptors (GPCRs) and Kinases are of enormous importance not only for the development of therapeutic drugs for the treatment of diseases but also for the understanding of stress-related (due to climate change) signaling in plants. In principle, the nature of conformational transition could be modeled in silico via atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, although this is very challenging due to the long activation timescales (in milliseconds). We employ a computational paradigm that couples cloud computing, transition pathway techniques and Markov State Model (MSM) based novel sampling algorithms for mapping the conformational landscape of proteins. These computations provide the thermodynamics and kinetics of their activation for the first time, and help identify key structural intermediates and novel allosteric sites for targeted design."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

We employ a computational paradigm that couples cloud computing, transition pathway techniques and Markov State Model (MSM) based novel sampling algorithms for mapping the conformational landscape of proteins. These computations provide the thermodynamics and kinetics of their activation for the first time, and help identify key structural intermediates and novel allosteric sites for targeted design."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list20985.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Thesis Defense, SCATTERING MECHANISMS IN HEAT TRANSPORT AT HIGH PRESSURE", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 9:00 am  ", "location" : "464 Loomis Lab", "bio" : "Mechanistic understanding of the large scale conformational transformations coupled with activation of key signaling proteins such as G-Protein Coupled Receptors (GPCRs) and Kinases are of enormous importance not only for the development of therapeutic drugs for the treatment of diseases but also for the understanding of stress-related (due to climate change) signaling in plants. In principle, the nature of conformational transition could be modeled in silico via atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, although this is very challenging due to the long activation timescales (in milliseconds). We employ a computational paradigm that couples cloud computing, transition pathway techniques and Markov State Model (MSM) based novel sampling algorithms for mapping the conformational landscape of proteins. These computations provide the thermodynamics and kinetics of their activation for the first time, and help identify key structural intermediates and novel allosteric sites for targeted design."}

{"doc_id": "list21004.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: ICMT Seminar: "The Puzzle of the Coulomb Energy in the Cuprates, Implications of Ellipsometric Measurements"", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "ESB 190", "bio" : "Some years ago, one of us [AJL PNAS 1999], proposed a scenario for cuprate superconductity in which the energy saving driving the transition is of Coulomb Energy (CE) in the long-wavelength, midinfrared frequency range. With minimal assumptions, this conjecture can be tested by measuring the optical loss function. The impetus for the present experimental and theoretical collaborative effort, was the observation, in the analysis of ellipsometric data on Bi-2223, of an anomaly in the integrated loss function at T1>Tc in the mid-infrared (MIR) range, and in the full frequency range (FR), and subsequently other data have been analyzed. The purpose is to examine the behavior, in the long-wavelength limit, of the CE of these HTSC, and the changes of the Loss Function at Tc and near Tc. "}

{"doc_id": "list21006.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Astronomy Colloquium - "Our Warped Universe: Strong Gravitational Lensing in the Dark Energy Survey and Timescapes from the Andes"", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:45 pm  ", "location" : "Astronomy 134", "bio" : "Several clues regarding the acceleration of space-time, dark matter and galaxy evolution in the early universe can be uncovered by studying strong gravitational lenses. The Dark Energy Survey (DES), which started observations in August 2013, is carrying out a wide-field survey of 5,000 square degrees of the Southern Galactic Cap. Much of this sky area has not yet been systematically surveyed, and we expect to discover many new strongly lensed galaxies and quasars. DES has identified 24 strong lens candidate objects (galaxy- and galaxy clusters-scale) in early data, and we have performed spectroscopic follow-up on a subset of these candidates at Gemini South and other telescopes. I will present results from the photometric and spectroscopic analysis of the lensing systems. In addition, we’ll watch the night sky from Cerro Tololo in the Andes (the site of DES operations) through snapshots and timescapes - from mountain life to the Milky Way."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21007.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: QI/AMO Seminar: "Coherent addressing of individual neutral atoms in a 3D optical lattice"", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "MRL 280", "bio" : "Neutral atoms in optical lattices are promising qubits; they have long coherences times and the number of qubits is naturally scalable. I will describe an experiment in which we coherently address individual neutral atoms in a 5×5×5 array formed by an optical lattice."}

{"doc_id": "list21008.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Theoretical Astrophysics and General Relativity Seminar:"Nucleosynthesis in the First Stars"", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "464 Loomis", "bio" : "The first stars to form in the universe likely had very different properties from later generation of stars. No direct observations of these star are possible at this time, however, so our ability to study these early stars is limited to indirect measurements and numerical simulations.  Stellar forensics based on nucleosynthesis patterns preserved in subsequent generations of stars may be used to attempt reconstruction of the properties of these first stars.  But in order to be able to use this tool, we need to know what abundances were synthesised in these first generations of stars."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21009.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Physics Colloquium: "Designing Superconductivity: Manipulating Interactions in Arrays of Superconducting Islands"", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "141 Loomis", "bio" : "One of the most fundamental questions in physics is how the macroscopic properties of matter emerge from microscopic constituents. Often, complex electronic correlations at the micro-scale act to create remarkable macroscopic materials properties, such as superconductivity and ferromagnetism. But the parameters relevant to understanding and manipulating these correlations are difficult to access. In this talk, I will discuss a "bottom-up" approach to studying collective effects in matter via nanostructured arrays of superconducting islands. We fabricate large arrays of superconducting islands patterned on normal metal films; by changing the size and configuration of the islands, we can to tune the parameters relevant to 2D superconductivity, such as disorder, dissipation, and phase separation. I will discuss electrical transport measurements of these systems, including characterization of the superconducting transitions, vortex dynamics in finite magnetic-fields, and evidence that the system approaches an unusual metallic ground state as the island spacing is increased. I will also discuss the mechanism behind the suppression of superconductivity in individual granular islands, even at large diameters."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21010.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Thesis Defense, SCATTERING MECHANISMS IN HEAT TRANSPORT AT HIGH PRESSURE", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 9:00 am  ", "location" : "464 Loomis Lab", "bio" : "link for robots only"}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21011.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Physics Careers Seminar: "An Introduction to Computational Lithography"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 11:00 am  ", "location" : "204 Loomis Laboratory (Interaction Room)", "bio" : "Moore's Law underpins the digital revolution that has been taking place in the past half century and counting. The central driver of Moore's Law is decades of breakthroughs in microlithography. In this talk, I will talk about my job as an engineer working in the field of computational lithography, which is a key enabler of lithography. I will also share a few career lessons that I have learned so far."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21012.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Condensed Matter Seminar: "Electronically-Induced Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped Cuprates and Iron Pnictides."", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "ESB 190", "bio" : "The relationship between electronic nematicity -- i.e. tetragonal symmetry-breaking induced by electronic rather than lattice degrees of freedom -- and unconventional superconductivity remains a widely investigated topic. The prime experimental tool to probe these nematic phases in cooper-based and iron-based superconductors is the in-plane resistivity anisotropy $\Delta\rho=\rho_{xx}-\rho_{yy}$, which, by symmetry arguments, must be proportional to the nematic order parameter $\eta$ near the nematic transition,  $\Delta\rho = C \eta$. In order to advance our understanding of the mechanisms and properties of the nematic phases, it is necessary however to go beyond phenomenological models and relate the proportionality constant $C$ to the collective behavior of the nematic Fermi fluid. In this work, we employ a Boltzmann equation approach to study how anisotropic fluctuations present in both underdoped  iron pnictides and cuprates are manifested in $\Delta\rho$, and, more specifically, in the proportionality constant $C$. We find in general two contributions to the resistivity anisotropy: one arising from the anisotropic scattering of the electrons by the actual fluctuations, which is dominant at higher temperatures, and a second one due to the anisotropic Fermi-velocity renormalization promoted by virtual fluctuations, which is dominant at lower temperatures. For the case of underdoped iron pnictides, for which anisotropic magnetic fluctuations are the lowest-energy excitations, we find that the two contributions yield generally the same sign of $C$, including its sign-change for sufficiently hole-doping. However, they differ in their dependence on the temperature and on the magnetic correlation length, which allows one to distinguish these two contributions experimentally. For the underdoped cuprates, not only anisotropic magnetic fluctuations, but also low-energy anisotropic charge fluctuations are present over a wide doping regime. We show that they give antagonistic contributions to the resistivity anisotropy, i.e. scattering of electrons by magnetic and charge fluctuations promote different signs for the proportionality constant $C$. We argue that these results qualitatively agree with the doping dependence of the resistivity anisotropy measured in detwinned orthorhombic YBCO, and discuss how they can be identified in strained tetragonal cuprates."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21013.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Biological Physics Seminar (CPLC): "May the force be with the Ring, or not - bacterial cytokinesis in superresolution"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "144 Loomis", "bio" : "During cytokinesis, a mechanical force constricts the cell envelope against an internal turgor pressure. In bacteria, this force is attributed to the essential 'divisome' machinery. The most conserved divisome component is the FtsZ ring, or Z-ring, which comprises protofilaments of the bacterial tubulin homolog and GTPase, FtsZ. Although the Z-ring has been a prevailing candidate for constrictive force generation, proposed force generation mechanisms have been difficult to test in vivo due to the essentiality of FtsZ, the limited ability to spatially resolve the Z-ring structure in small bacterial cells, and the lack of sensitive methods to monitor Z-ring contraction and the rate of septum closure during cytokinesis. We applied quantitative single-molecule based superresolution imaging with other biophysical techniques and genetic manipulations to examine the structure of the Z-ring and its contraction during cytokinesis. Our results challenge the FtsZ-centric view of constrictive force generation in bacteria, and suggest that FtsZ should be viewed as a key structural scaffold, regulator, or mediator rather than as a major force generator."}

{"doc_id": "list21017.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: The Secrets in their landscapes: Elucidating conformational preferences of proteins for design of allosteric modulators", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 3:00 pm - 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "3269 Beckman", "bio" : "Mechanistic understanding of the large scale conformational transformations coupled with activation of key signaling proteins such as G-Protein Coupled Receptors (GPCRs) and Kinases are of enormous importance not only for the development of therapeutic drugs for the treatment of diseases but also for the understanding of stress-related (due to climate change) signaling in plants. In principle, the nature of conformational transition could be modeled in silico via atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, although this is very challenging due to the long activation timescales (in milliseconds). We employ a computational paradigm that couples cloud computing, transition pathway techniques and Markov State Model (MSM) based novel sampling algorithms for mapping the conformational landscape of proteins. These computations provide the thermodynamics and kinetics of their activation for the first time, and help identify key structural intermediates and novel allosteric sites for targeted design."}

{"doc_id": "list21024.txt", "event" : "Physics Illinois | University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: Physics Colloquium: "Atomic-scale Antagonism between d-Symmetry Cooper Pairs and d-Symmetry Density Waves in Cuprate Superconductors"", "date" : " May 6, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "141 Loomis", "bio" : "            A central issue of research into the high temperature superconducting copper-oxides is to understand the nature of the pseudogap phase and its relationship to the d-symmetry superconductivity. Using our recently developed technique of sub-lattice phase-resolved electronic structure visualization within each CuO2 unit-cell [1], we found that the density wave observed in the cuprate pseudogap regime, itself exhibits d-symmetry [2]. Although long predicted, such an unconventional density-wave state has not previously been observed in any condensed matter system. Our simultaneous visualizations of both real-space and momentum-space electronic structure across the cuprate phase diagram then revealed that the transition of Fermi surface topology from the mysterious “Fermi arc” to conventional Fermi surface occurs simultaneously with the disappearance of the d-symmetry density wave [3]. Taken together these results provide key information on the microscopic mechanism of the d-symmetry density wave state, and on the antagonism between it and the d-symmetry Cooper pairing."}

{"doc_id": "list21081.txt", "event" : "Prairie Research Institute: ISGS Seminar Series: Thermal evolution of mountain belts: from the atomic to the orogenic scale", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 11:00 am  ", "location" : "Room 101, Natural Resources Building", "bio" : "In its modern reincarnation as a low‐temperature thermochronometer, the (U‐Th)/He dating technique has served an important role in our understanding of a range of geologic processes. Of the various questions it can address, the chronometer’s ability to constrain the exhumation histories of rocks makes it a particularly useful tool for describing the evolution of active and ancient orogens. Despite the prevalent use of (U‐Th)/He thermochronometry, our understanding of the fundamental kinetics of He diffusion in the minerals of interest—i.e. the governing principles behind the method—remain limited. In this talk, I’ll discuss our recent efforts to better understand He diffusion in one particularly useful mineral, zircon, and demonstrate how this new knowledge has opened‐up novel approaches to interpreting previously indecipherable datasets from various orogenic belts."}

{"doc_id": "list21084.txt", "event" : "Prairie Research Institute: ISGS Seminar Series: Reinterpretation of mechanisms of the New Madrid earthquake", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 11:00 am  ", "location" : "Room 101, Natural Resources Building", "bio" : "Show upcoming events, starting with today"}

{"doc_id": "list21085.txt", "event" : "Prairie Research Institute: ISTC - Sustainable Seminar Series - How sustainable is information technology? Trends, challenges, and opportunities (Webinar)", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm - 1:00 pm  ", "location" : "Illinois Sustainable Technology Center, One E. Hazelwood Dr., Champaign, IL 61820", "bio" : "The growing numbers of information technology (IT) devices—and the environmental impacts associated with their manufacture, use, and disposal—are topics that have received much attention in both the media and research communities.  While the environmental footprint of IT devices is indeed significant, each new device generation typically brings substantial operational energy efficiency improvements.  Furthermore, a singular focus on their direct impacts ignores the indirect environmental benefits that IT devices might provide by improving societal energy and resource efficiencies.   A growing body of research suggests that such benefits might be substantial across the economy through such applications as replacing physical goods with digital services, building controls for energy efficiency, and real-time logistics optimization. This presentation will review the life-cycle impacts of IT systems, discuss trends in these impacts as a function of technology progress and growing consumption over time, and highlight the challenges and opportunities associated with managing and reducing the environmental impacts of IT systems moving forward."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21086.txt", "event" : "Prairie Research Institute: Discovering Late Victorian East St. Louis: Urban Archaeology and the New Mississippi River Bridge Project", "date" : " May 17, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "950 North Lombard, Rt 47, Mahomet, Illinois", "bio" : "Between 2009 and 2012, teams of archaeologists from the Illinois State Archaeological Survey (ISAS) conducted large-scale excavations in East St. Louis as part of the New Mississippi River Bridge Project. The recovered artifacts and information, combined with archival research, are yielding new insights into the history of East St. Louis, particularly about the daily lives of working-class individuals and families from the time when the city was a booming transportation and manufacturing hub. The project’s path cut through former residential neighborhoods and remnants of the St. Louis National Stockyards, which lead to the recovery of thousands of artifacts from privies, cisterns, wells, and cellars. This presentation examines the excavation and material culture associated with this Late Victorian East St.Louis working class neighborhood."}

{"doc_id": "list21453.txt", "event" : "SLAVIC Calendar « About Us « Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures, University of Illinois: The Twenty-Fifth Arnold O. Beckman Lecture on Science and Innovation", "date" : " May 4, 2015", "time" : " 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "Ballroom, Alice Campbell Alumni Center, 601 South Lincoln Avenue; Urbana IL", "bio" : "Everything around us, everything each of us has ever experienced, and virtually everything underpinning our technological society and economy is governed by quantum mechanics. Yet this most fundamental physical theory of nature often feels as if it is a set of somewhat eerie and counterintuitive ideas of no direct relevance to our lives. Why is this? One reason is that we cannot perceive the strangeness (and astonishing beauty) of the quantum mechanical phenomena all around us by using our own senses."}

{"doc_id": "list21508.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Schwarzman Scholarship Information Session", "date" : " Apr 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "Join us to learn about the exciting new Schwarzman Scholarship Program, which is currently holding its inaugural competition! The Schwarzman provides a year of study leading to a Master's degree in Public Policy, Economics and Business, or International Studies at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. All courses are taught in English. Seniors, graduate or professional students, and graduates under the age of 28 are eligible to apply. U.S. and non-U.S. citizens are eligible.  Our informational session is targeted to juniors, seniors, and graduate or professional students, and will provide an overview of the program, including selection criteria, application process, and the benefits provided to the selected scholars.  The priority deadline for the Schwarzman Scholarship is June 1, 2015, and the required campus deadline is August 25, 2015, so now is the time to learn about the program and get answers to your questions!"}

{"doc_id": "list21511.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: UK and Ireland Scholarships Informational Session and Application Workshop", "date" : " May 7, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 5:00 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB 514)", "bio" : "Join us to learn about a group of nationally competitive scholarships that fully fund graduate study in the United Kingdom and Ireland! This informational session and application workshop is targeted to juniors, seniors, and graduate or professional students, and will provide an overview of the Gates Cambridge, Marshall, Mitchell, and Rhodes scholarships.  We will discuss basic eligibility requirements, selection criteria, and the application processes for these awards.  The latter portion of the event is designed to introduce some of the common application components for the scholarships and help participants start to develop content for them.  This is a great opportunity to strategize and get feedback on your ideas for your personal statement and other written portions of the applications.  The priority deadline for the Marshall and Gates Cambridge scholarships is June 1, 2015, and the required campus deadline for many of the UK/Ireland scholarships is August 25, 2015, so now is the time to learn about the programs and get answers to your questions!"}

This is a need based award, and to be eligible, students currently must be receiving a Federal Pell Grant.  The National and International Scholarships Program is willing to assist in reviewing your scholarship application material, in fact, we welcome the opportunity to help make your application more competitive!  As such, we are offering a two-day informational event about the Gilman Scholarship. September 3rd from 3:30-4:30 is an informational session and alumni Q&A.  September 4th between 3:30-4:30 is a workshop on how to craft your application essays."}

{"doc_id": "list21524.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Truman Scholarship Workshop", "date" : " Oct 16, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "This workshop’s purpose is to help get you started on your Truman Scholarship application. Aspiring nominees will receive tips on application components and leave with some text crafted for many of the sections of a Truman application. The Truman program is looking for the academically strong student who has a passion for public service. Evaluators look for leadership ability, potential for influencing public policies, community service and extracurricular involvement, strong academic performance, and potential to perform well in a graduate school program. It awards $30,000 merit-based scholarships to U.S. citizen college students who wish to attend graduate school in preparation for careers in public service.  Public service includes a wide array of career possibilities, such as public health; local, state, or federal government; educational policy; international relations; conservation; and environmental protection. Candidates should be able to demonstrate leadership experiences in campus and community service activities. Truman Scholars have pursued many fields of study, such as agriculture, engineering, economics, education, government, history, international relations, law, political science, public administration, and public health. Scholars are required to work in public service for three of the seven years following completion of a Foundation funded graduate degree program as a condition of receiving funding."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21525.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Goldwater Scholarship Information Session", "date" : " Oct 22, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "The National and International Scholarships Program is offering a two-day event about the Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship. The Goldwater Scholarship offers $7,500 to either sophomores or juniors in STEM disciplines who aim to pursue a Ph.D. in their field.  On October 22, attendants will receive an overview of the scholarship as well as have a chance to talk with a former Goldwater Scholarship recipient from Illinois.  On October 23, the Scholarships Program will offer a workshop on how to write a competitive scholarship packet.  Students are encouraged to attend both events.  All events will be held in 514 IUB.  Thursday, October 22 from 3:30-4:30 is the overview and discussion with a former Goldwater Scholar and Friday, October 23 from 3:30-4:30 is the workshop on how to craft a competitive application packet."}

{"doc_id": "list21527.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Boren Undergraduate Scholarship Information Session", "date" : " Oct 29, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "The University of Illinois will be hosting informational sessions on National Security Education Program Boren undergraduate study abroad scholarships.  Participants will receive information about the program and converse with an Illinois alumni recipient.  The campus application deadline is in January 2016 for any semester or year of study between May 2016 and May 2017. Students are encouraged to begin application drafts prior to leaving for winter break.  The Boren provides study abroad scholarships of $6,000-$20,000 for a full academic year or $4,000-$10,000 for a semester. Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students also have the option of applying for summer-only programs of eight weeks or more. All scholarships may be used for U.S. citizens to study in Asia, Africa, Central & Eastern Europe, Latin America, or the Middle East on almost any study abroad program. These are merit-based scholarships (approximately 1 in 5 eligible applicants receive awards). In order to receive the scholarship, award winners must enter into a service agreement requiring that they attempt to work in a paid position for the federal government in an area related to national security—generally the Departments of State, Defense, Homeland Security, or the Intelligence Community within three years of graduation (deferrals possible/encouraged for graduate study). Working for USAID or tenure in the Peace Corps counts in the service requirement. Winners also receive priority-hiring status.  The Boren information session will be held on October 29th from 3:30-4:30 in IUB room 514 and the Boren workshop will be held on October 30th from 3:30-4:30 in IUB room 514.  For more information on the Boren you can visit http://topscholars.illinois.edu/prestigious/nsep.html."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21528.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Boren Undergraduate Scholarship Workshop", "date" : " Oct 30, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "The University of Illinois will be hosting an event on National Security Education Program Boren undergraduate study abroad scholarships.  This workshop will provide tips and help students get started on their actual applications. The campus application deadline is January 2016 for any semester or year of study between May 2016 and May 2017. Students are encouraged to begin application drafts prior to leaving for winter break.  The Boren provides study abroad scholarships of $6,000-$20,000 for a full academic year or $4,000-$10,000 for a semester. Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students also have the option of applying for summer-only programs of eight weeks or more. All scholarships may be used for U.S. citizens to study in Asia, Africa, Central & Eastern Europe, Latin America, or the Middle East on almost any study abroad program. These are merit-based scholarships (approximately 1 in 5 eligible applicants receive awards). In order to receive the scholarship, award winners must enter into a service agreement requiring that they attempt to work in a paid position for the federal government in an area related to national security—generally the Departments of State, Defense, Homeland Security, or the Intelligence Community within three years of graduation (deferrals possible/encouraged for graduate study). Working for USAID or tenure in the Peace Corps counts in the service requirement. Winners also receive priority-hiring status.  This workshop is intended to help you get started on your application for the Boren Scholarship."}

{"doc_id": "list21529.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Beinecke Scholarship Information Session", "date" : " Nov 5, 2015", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "If you are a high-achieving junior and are planning to attend graduate school after graduation, but have concerns about being able to afford it, consider applying for the Beinecke Scholarship. The National and International Scholarships Program has planned two sessions to assist students towards earning this $34,000 award. On Thursday, November 5, we will be conducting an informational session, including a question and answer period with an Illini recipient, from 3:30-4:30 in IUB room 514 and on November 6, a Beinecke workshop from 3:30-4:30 in IUB room 514 to help students get started on their actual applications.  The Beinecke Foundation is looking for students who have demonstrated superior standards of intellectual ability, scholastic achievement, and personal promise during their undergraduate years. The program seeks to encourage and enable highly motivated U.S. citizen juniors to pursue graduate studies in the arts, humanities, and social sciences. Each scholar receives $4,000 immediately prior to entering graduate school and an additional $30,000 while attending graduate school. Preference is given to candidates for whom the awarding of significant financial aid would increase the likelihood of the student's being able to attend graduate school."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}

{"doc_id": "list21536.txt", "event" : "Scholarships Office Master Calendar: Gilman Information Session", "date" : " Feb 4, 2016", "time" : " 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm  ", "location" : "807 S. Wright St., Floor 5 (IUB Room 514)", "bio" : "The Gilman International Scholarship Program provides awards of $5,000 (plus up to a $3,000 supplement for critical languages) for U.S. citizen undergraduate students to pursue summer, semester, or academic-year study abroad opportunities in other countries. This is a need based award, and to be eligible, students currently must be receiving a Federal Pell Grant.  The National and International Scholarships Program is willing to assist in reviewing your scholarship application material, in fact, we welcome the opportunity to help make your application more competitive!  As such, we are offering a two-day informational event about the Gilman Scholarship. February 4th from 3:30-4:30 is an informational session and alumni Q&A. February 5th between 3:30-4:30 is a workshop on how to craft your application essays."}

{"doc_id": "list21676.txt", "event" : "Seminars of Interest: Biochemistry Seminar: Dr. Lynette Cegelski (Stanford University), "Structure, Function, and Inhibition of Bacterial Cell Walls and Biofilms: Lessons from Small Molecules and a Big Magnet"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "Charles G. Miller Auditorium (B102 CLSL)", "bio" : "ABSTRACT:  The bacterial cell wall is essential to cell viability and is a major target of antibiotics. Beyond the cell wall and the cell surface, bacteria secrete proteins and polysaccharides to enmesh themselves in a protective biofilm matrix that enhances bacterial resistance to antibiotics. As heterogeneous, insoluble polymeric matrices, cell walls and biofilms pose a challenge to analysis by conventional methods. We are developing new approaches to dissect composition in cell walls and whole cells and to transform vague biofilm descriptors into quantitative parameters of chemical and molecular composition. In our drug discovery efforts, we have identified small-molecule biofilm inhibitors and are examining their influence on biofilm formation and on pathogenesis in vivo. I will discuss these and our emerging discoveries inspired by the urgent need for new strategies to treat infectious diseases, integrating bacteriology, biochemistry, and whole-cell NMR, specifically targeting E. coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Vibrio cholerae."}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list21677.txt", "event" : "Seminars of Interest: Biological Physics Seminar (CPLC): "May the force be with the Ring, or not - bacterial cytokinesis in superresolution"", "date" : " May 1, 2015", "time" : " 2:00 pm  ", "location" : "144 Loomis", "bio" : "During cytokinesis, a mechanical force constricts the cell envelope against an internal turgor pressure. In bacteria, this force is attributed to the essential 'divisome' machinery. The most conserved divisome component is the FtsZ ring, or Z-ring, which comprises protofilaments of the bacterial tubulin homolog and GTPase, FtsZ. Although the Z-ring has been a prevailing candidate for constrictive force generation, proposed force generation mechanisms have been difficult to test in vivo due to the essentiality of FtsZ, the limited ability to spatially resolve the Z-ring structure in small bacterial cells, and the lack of sensitive methods to monitor Z-ring contraction and the rate of septum closure during cytokinesis. We applied quantitative single-molecule based superresolution imaging with other biophysical techniques and genetic manipulations to examine the structure of the Z-ring and its contraction during cytokinesis. Our results challenge the FtsZ-centric view of constrictive force generation in bacteria, and suggest that FtsZ should be viewed as a key structural scaffold, regulator, or mediator rather than as a major force generator."}

{"doc_id": "list22356.txt", "event" : "Speakers Calendar | ILLINOIS: ICMT Seminar: "The Puzzle of the Coulomb Energy in the Cuprates, Implications of Ellipsometric Measurements"", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "ESB 190", "bio" : "Some years ago, one of us [AJL PNAS 1999], proposed a scenario for cuprate superconductity in which the energy saving driving the transition is of Coulomb Energy (CE) in the long-wavelength, midinfrared frequency range. With minimal assumptions, this conjecture can be tested by measuring the optical loss function. The impetus for the present experimental and theoretical collaborative effort, was the observation, in the analysis of ellipsometric data on Bi-2223, of an anomaly in the integrated loss function at T1>Tc in the mid-infrared (MIR) range, and in the full frequency range (FR), and subsequently other data have been analyzed. The purpose is to examine the behavior, in the long-wavelength limit, of the CE of these HTSC, and the changes of the Loss Function at Tc and near Tc. "}
{ "create": { "_index": "team_index", "_type": "doc"}}
{"doc_id": "list22357.txt", "event" : "Speakers Calendar | ILLINOIS: Materials Science and Engineering Colloquium", "date" : " Apr 27, 2015", "time" : " 4:00 pm  ", "location" : "100 Materials Science and Engineering Building", "bio" : ""Billions and billions of molecules: Exploring chemical space" - Many of the challenges of the twenty-first century are related to molecular processes such as the generation, transmission, and storage of clean energy, water purification and desalination. These transformations require a next generation of more efficient and ecologically-friendly materials. In the life sciences, we face similar challenges, for example drug-resistant bacterial strains require novel antibiotics. One of the paradigm shifts that the theoretical and experimental chemists needs to embrace is that of accelerated molecular discovery: The design cycles need to be sped up by the constant interaction of theoreticians and experimentalists, the use of high-throughput computational techniques, tools from machine learning and big data, and the development of public materials databases. I will describe three projects from my research group that aim to operate in this accelerated design cycle. First, I will describe our efforts on the Harvard Clean Energy Project (http://cleanenergy.harvard.edu), a search for materials for organic solar cells. I will continue by talking about our work on developing organic molecules for energy storage in flow batteries. Finally, I will describe our work towards the discovery of novel molecules for organic light-emitting diodes."}

{"doc_id": "list22360.txt", "event" : "Speakers Calendar | ILLINOIS: Astronomy Colloquium - "Our Warped Universe: Strong Gravitational Lensing in the Dark Energy Survey and Timescapes from the Andes"", "date" : " Apr 28, 2015", "time" : " 3:45 pm  ", "location" : "Astronomy 134", "bio" : "Several clues regarding the acceleration of space-time, dark matter and galaxy evolution in the early universe can be uncovered by studying strong gravitational lenses. The Dark Energy Survey (DES), which started observations in August 2013, is carrying out a wide-field survey of 5,000 square degrees of the Southern Galactic Cap. Much of this sky area has not yet been systematically surveyed, and we expect to discover many new strongly lensed galaxies and quasars. DES has identified 24 strong lens candidate objects (galaxy- and galaxy clusters-scale) in early data, and we have performed spectroscopic follow-up on a subset of these candidates at Gemini South and other telescopes. I will present results from the photometric and spectroscopic analysis of the lensing systems. In addition, we’ll watch the night sky from Cerro Tololo in the Andes (the site of DES operations) through snapshots and timescapes - from mountain life to the Milky Way."}

{"doc_id": "list22365.txt", "event" : "Speakers Calendar | ILLINOIS: Theoretical Astrophysics and General Relativity Seminar:"Nucleosynthesis in the First Stars"", "date" : " Apr 29, 2015", "time" : " 12:00 pm  ", "location" : "464 Loomis", "bio" : "The first stars to form in the universe likely had very different properties from later generation of stars. No direct observations of these star are possible at this time, however, so our ability to study these early stars is limited to indirect measurements and numerical simulations.  Stellar forensics based on nucleosynthesis patterns preserved in subsequent generations of stars may be used to attempt reconstruction of the properties of these first stars.  But in order to be able to use this tool, we need to know what abundances were synthesised in these first generations of stars."}
